Language Use in the United States: 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614060228/http://www.census.gov/hhes/socdemo/language/data/acs/ACS-12.pdf |date=2013-06-14 }} || {{n/a}} || 12,000 || 118,000 || 10,800 |- | ''Sum'' || '''''4,597,392''''' || '''''3,000,000''''' || '''''357,360''''' || '''''133,000''''' || '''''34,000''''' |} ==Africa== ===Namibia=== [[Image:NamibiaDeutscheSprache.jpg|thumb|Examples of German language in Namibia's everyday life.]] {{Main|German language in Namibia}} Namibia used to be [[German South-West Africa|a colony]] of the [[German Empire]] from 1884 to 1919. Mostly originating from German settlers who immigrated during this time, 25,000 to 30,000 people still speak German as a native tongue today.{{cite web|url=http://www.az.com.na/fileadmin/pdf/2007/deutsch_in_namibia_2007_07_18.pdf|title=Deutsch in Namibia|publisher=Supplement of the Allgemeine Zeitung|date=18 August 2007|accessdate=23 June 2008|format=PDF|language=German|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624233949/http://www.az.com.na/fileadmin/pdf/2007/deutsch_in_namibia_2007_07_18.pdf|archivedate=24 June 2008|df=}} German, along with English and [[Afrikaans]] used to be a co-official language of Namibia from 1984 until its independence from [[South Africa]] in 1990. At this point, the Namibian government perceived Afrikaans and German as symbols for [[Apartheid]] and colonialism, and decided for English to be the sole official language, claiming that it was a "neutral" language as virtually no English native speakers existed in Namibia at that time. German, Afrikaans and several indigenous languages became "national languages" by law, identifying them as cultural heritages of the nation and ensuring the state to acknowledge and support their presence in the country. Today, German is used in a wide variety of spheres, especially business and tourism, as well as churches (most notably the German-speaking [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in Namibia (GELK)]]), schools (e.g. the [[Deutsche Höhere Privatschule Windhoek]]), literature (German-Namibian authors include [[:de:Giselher W. Hoffmann|Giselher W. Hoffmann]]), radio (the [[Namibian Broadcasting Corporation]] produces radio programs in German), and music (e.g. artist [[EES (rapper)|EES]]). The [[Allgemeine Zeitung (Namibia)|Allgemeine Zeitung]] is also one of the three biggest newspapers in Namibia and the only German-language daily in Africa. ===South Africa=== Mostly originating from different waves of immigration during the 19th and 20th centuries, an estimated 12,000 people speak German or a German variety as a first language in [[South Africa]].[[Template:German L1 speakers outside Europe|German L1 speakers outside Europe]] Germans settled quite extensively in South Africa, with many [[Calvinist]]s immigrating from Northern Europe. Later on, more Germans settled in the [[KwaZulu-Natal]] and elsewhere. Here, one of the largest communities are the speakers of "Nataler Deutsch", a variety of [[Low German]], who are concentrated in and around [[Wartburg, KwaZulu-Natal|Wartburg]]. German is slowly disappearing elsewhere, but a number of communities still have a large number of speakers and some even have German language schools. Furthermore, German was often a language taught as a foreign language in White South African schools during the Apartheid years (1948-1994). Today, the South African constitution identifies German as a "commonly used" language and the [[Pan South African Language Board]] is obligated to promote and ensure respect for it.{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.za/documents/constitution/chapter-1-founding-provisions#5|title=Constitution of the Republic of South Africa, 1996 - Chapter 1: Founding Provisions - South African Government|website=www.gov.za|accessdate=4 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141028043044/http://www.gov.za/documents/constitution/chapter-1-founding-provisions#5|archivedate=28 October 2014|df=}} ==Australia== Australia has an estimated population of around 75,600 German speakers. Australians of German ancestry constitute the fourth largest ethnic group in Australia, numbering around 811,540. German immigrants played a significant role in settling the states of [[South Australia]] and [[Queensland]]. [[Barossa German]], a dialect of German, was once common in and around the German-settled [[Barossa Valley]] in [[South Australia]]. However, the German language was actively suppressed by Australian governments during [[World War I]] and [[World War II]], resulting in a sharp decline in the use of German in Australia. [[German Australian]]s are today overwhelmingly English speaking, with the German language as a home language in heavy decline. ==Europe== ===DACH countries=== {{Pie chart |caption=Approximate distribution of native German speakers (assuming a rounded total of 95 million) worldwide.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} |value1=78.3 |label1=[[Germany]] |color1=Black |value2=8.4 |label2=[[Austria]] |color2=Yellow |value3=5.6 |label3=[[Switzerland]] |color3=#FF0000 |value4=0.4 |label4=[[Italy]] |color4=#008751 |value5=7.3 |label5=Other |color5=Grey }} The [[German language]] is spoken in a number of countries and territories in [[Europe]], where it is used both as an official language and as a minority language in various countries. To cover this language area, they are often referred to as the German-speaking countries, the German-speaking area ({{lang|de|Deutscher [[Sprachraum]]}}), or equivalently German-speaking Europe (non-European German-speaking communities are not commonly included in the concept). German is the main language of approximately 95 to 100 million people in Europe, or 13.3% of all Europeans, being the second most spoken native language in Europe after [[Russian language|Russian]] (with 144 million speakers), above [[French language|French]] (with 66.5 million) and [[English language|English]] (with 64.2 million). The European countries with German-speaking majorities are [[Languages of Germany|Germany]] (95%, 78.3 million), [[Languages of Austria|Austria]] (89%, 7.4 million) and [[Linguistic geography of Switzerland|Switzerland]] (65%, 4.6 million), also known as "D-A-CH" countries. Other European countries and regions with a German-speaking majority include [[Liechtenstein]] (0.03 million), the Italian autonomous region of South-Tyrol (0.5 million) and the [[German-speaking Community of Belgium]] with around 70.000 native speakers. Since 2004, there is an annual informal meeting of the heads of state of German-speaking countries including the Presidents of Germany, Austria and Switzerland and the Hereditary Prince of Liechtenstein.[http://www.bundespraesident.de/SharedDocs/Berichte/EN/Joachim-Gauck/2012/06/120611-Switzerland.html Meeting of German-speaking heads of state] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905143417/http://www.bundespraesident.de/SharedDocs/Berichte/EN/Joachim-Gauck/2012/06/120611-Switzerland.html |date=2017-09-05 }} Since 2014 the King of [[Belgium]] and the Grand Duke of [[Luxembourg]] have also been taking part.[http://www.bundespraesident.de/SharedDocs/Berichte/DE/Joachim-Gauck/2015/09/150916-Liechtenstein-Staatsoberhaeupter.html Meeting of German-speaking heads of state in 2015] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180101030015/http://www.bundespraesident.de/SharedDocs/Berichte/DE/Joachim-Gauck/2015/09/150916-Liechtenstein-Staatsoberhaeupter.html |date=2018-01-01 }} D-A-CH or DACH is an [[acronym]] used to represent the dominant states of the [[German language]] ''[[Sprachraum]]''. It is based on the [[List of international vehicle registration codes|international vehicle registration codes]] for: * [[Germany]] (D for ''Deutschland'') * [[Austria]] (A for ''Austria'', in [[German language|German]] "Österreich") * [[Switzerland]] (CH for ''Confoederatio Helvetica'', in [[German language|German]] "(die) Schweiz") "Dach" is also the German word for "roof", and is used in linguistics in the term [[Dachsprache]], which standard German arguably is in relation to some outlying dialects of German, especially in Switzerland, France, Luxembourg and Austria. The term is sometimes extended to D-A-CH-Li, DACHL or DACH+ to include [[Liechtenstein]]. Another version is DACHS (with ''Dachs'' meaning "[[Badger]]" in German) with the inclusion of the German-speaking region of [[South Tyrol]] in [[Italy]].Example: [http://www.claudiana.bz.it/de/projekte/esf_projekt_ergotherapie_2010_dachs_projekt_.html DACHS-Projekt "Ergotherapie 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722025418/http://www.claudiana.bz.it/de/projekte/esf_projekt_ergotherapie_2010_dachs_projekt_.html |date=2011-07-22 }} DACH is also the name of an [[Interreg]] IIIA project, which focuses on crossborder cooperation in planning.{{cite web|title=DACH+ Raumentwicklung im Grenzraum von Deutschland, Österreich, Schweiz und Liechtenstein|language=German|publisher=DACH|url=http://www.d-a-ch.org/|accessdate=2008-03-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321024810/http://www.d-a-ch.org/|archivedate=2008-03-21|df=}} ===Rest of Europe=== In the [[Early Modern period]], German varieties were a ''[[lingua franca]]'' of Central, Eastern and [[Northern Europe]] ([[Hanseatic League]]).{{cite book|last1=von Polenz|first1=Peter|title=Deutsche Sprachgeschichte vom Spätmittelalter bis zur Gegenwart|volume=Band III: 19. und 20. Jahrhundert|series=de Gruyter Studienbuch|date=1999|publisher=de Gruyter|location=Berlin; New York|isbn=3-11-016426-4|pages=192–194, 196|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b1KF3f-aGR4C&pg=PA193&lpg=PA193&dq=deutsch+verkehrssprache+nordeuropa|accessdate=21 August 2014|language=German|chapter=6.5. Inter- und übernationale Beziehungen}} Today, German, together with [[French language|French]], is a common second foreign language in the western world, as [[English language|English]] is well established as a first foreign language. German ranks second (after English) among the best known foreign languages in the EU (on par with French) as well as in [[Russia]].{{cite web |script-title=ru:Знание иностранных языков в России |trans-title=Knowledge of foreign languages in Russia |language=Russian |url=http://www.levada.ru/16-09-2008/znanie-inostrannykh-yazykov-v-rossii |publisher=Levada Centre |accessdate=10 May 2015 |date=16 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510133101/http://www.levada.ru/16-09-2008/znanie-inostrannykh-yazykov-v-rossii |archivedate=10 May 2015 |df= }} In terms of student numbers across all levels of education, German ranks third in the EU (after English and French){{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Foreign_language_learning_statistics|title=Foreign language learning statistics - Statistics Explained|website=ec.europa.eu|accessdate=4 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628100813/http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Foreign_language_learning_statistics|archivedate=28 June 2017|df=}} as well as in the United States (after Spanish and French).{{cite web |url=http://www.actfl.org/sites/default/files/pdfs/ReportSummary2011.pdf |title=Foreign Language Enrollments in K–12 Public Schools |date=February 2011 |publisher=American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) |access-date=October 17, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160408184754/http://www.actfl.org/sites/default/files/pdfs/ReportSummary2011.pdf |archivedate=April 8, 2016 |df= }}[[Modern Language Association]], February 2015, [http://www.mla.org/pdf/2013_enrollment_survey.pdf Enrollments in Languages Other Than English in United States Institutions of Higher Education, Fall 2013] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404015237/http://www.mla.org/pdf/2013_enrollment_survey.pdf |date=2015-04-04 }}. Retrieved 2015-07-07. In 2015, approximately 15.4 million people were in the process of learning German across all levels of education worldwide.{{cite web|url=https://www.goethe.de/resources/files/pdf37/Bro_Deutschlernerhebung_final3.pdf|title=Deutsch als Fremdsprache weltweit. Datenerhebung 2015 - Worldwide survey of people learning German; conducted by the German Ministry for Foreign Affairs and the Goethe Institute|publisher=|accessdate=4 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170525142613/https://www.goethe.de/resources/files/pdf37/Bro_Deutschlernerhebung_final3.pdf|archivedate=25 May 2017|df=}} As this number remained relatively stable since 2005 (± 1 million), roughly 75–100 million people able to communicate in German as foreign language can be inferred assuming an average course duration of three years and other estimated parameters.[http://www.ulrichammon.de/resources/Stellung_der_deutschen_Sprache.pdf Ammon, Ulrich - Die Stellung der deutschen Sprache in der Welt] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151109200453/http://www.ulrichammon.de/resources/Stellung_der_deutschen_Sprache.pdf |date=2015-11-09 }} (de Gruyter Mouton; {{ISBN|978-3-11-019298-8}}) According to a 2012 survey, ca. 47 million people within the EU (i.e., up to two thirds of the 75-100 million worldwide) claimed to have sufficient German skills to have a conversation. Within the EU, and not counting countries where it is a (co-)official language, German as a foreign language is most widely taught in [[Eastern Europe|Eastern]] and [[Northern Europe]], namely the [[Czech Republic]], [[Croatia]], [[Denmark]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Slovakia]], [[Slovenia]], [[Sweden]] and [[Poland]]. German as a foreign language is promoted by the [[Goethe Institute]], which works to promote German language and culture worldwide. In association with the Goethe Institute, the German foreign broadcasting service, [[Deutsche Welle]], offers a range of online German courses{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/0,2142,2547,00.html|title=German Courses - DW|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(www.dw.com)|website=DW.COM|accessdate=4 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120117071036/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/0,2142,2547,00.html|archivedate=17 January 2012|df=}} and worldwide television as well as radio broadcasts produced with non-native German speakers in mind.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/|title=TOP STORIES - DW|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(www.dw.com)|website=DW.COM|accessdate=4 July 2017}}

==Latin America== At least one million German speakers live in Latin America. There are German speaking minorities in almost every [[Latin American]] country, including [[Argentina]], [[Belize]], [[Bolivia]], [[Brazil]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Dominican Republic]], [[Ecuador]], [[Guatemala]], [[Mexico]], [[Nicaragua]], [[Paraguay]], [[Peru]], [[Uruguay]] and [[Venezuela]]. In the eighteenth century only isolated or small groups of German emigrants left for Latin America. However this pattern was reversed at the start of the last century as a tidal wave of German emigration began. German emigration to [[the Americas]] totalled 200,000 people during the eighteenth century. During the 1880s, during the wave of mass emigration, this figure was reached annually. The ''Handbuch des Deutschtums im Ausland'' (''The Germans Abroad Handbook'') from 1906 puts a figure of 11 million people in North and South America with a knowledge of the German language, of which 9 million were in the US. Although the US was the focal point for emigration in the 19th century, emigration to Latin America was also significant for differing economic and political reasons. The majority of German emigrants to Latin America went especially to Brazil but also to: Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, Paraguay, Guatemala, and Costa Rica.{{cite book |title=Hitler's Man in Havana: Heinz Luning and Nazi Espionage in Latin America |date=2008 |publisher=The University Press of Kentucky |location=United States of America |isbn=978-0-8131-2501-5 |page=35 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CojTWMNxso4C&lpg=PA35 |accessdate=27 May 2014}} Starting in 1818, when King D. João VI brought the first German and Swiss immigrants to Brazil, German immigration continued a constant flow with an average of 25 to 30 thousand immigrants per decade entering the country since 1818. It peaked in the years following World War I, to around 90 thousand, and again in the 1940s to around 50,000. In the 1880s and 1890s, German emigration to Latin America grew and in some years was the destination of up to 30% of German emigrants. During the Nazi period - until the ban on emigration came into effect in 1941 - some 100,000 Jews from Central Europe, the vast majority of which were German speaking, moved to South America with 90% of these moving to the Cono Sur or Southern Cone. From the start of the 20th century until 1946 80% of Jews lived in Europe but by the end of [[World War II]] this was reduced to 25%, however after the war over 50% of Jews now lived in [[the Americas]]. This change was aided by [[Jewish emigration]] groups such as the [[Hilfsverein deutschsprechender Juden]] (later to become [[Asociación Filantrópica Israelita]]) which was based in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. The majority of [[German minority|German minorities]] in [[Latin America]] - as well as elsewhere around the world - experienced a decline in the use of the German language, with the exception of Brazil, where the dialect Riograndenser Hunsrückisch is being taught in schools and in some media, totaling over 200 thousand speakers spread over the Brazilian southern states. The main cause of this decrease is the integration of communities, often originally sheltered, into the dominant society, and then modernisation after assimilation into society which confronts all immigrant groups. Specific reasons for language change from German to the national language usually derive from the desire of many Germans to belong to their new communities after the end of World War II. This is a common feature among the German minorities in Latin America and those in [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]]: the majority of countries where German minorities lived had fought against the Germans during the war. With this change in situation the members of the German minorities, previously communities of status and prestige, were turned into undesirable minorities (though there were widespread elements of sympathy for Germany in many South American countries as well). For many German minorities WWII thus represented the breaking point in the development of their language. In some South American countries the war period and immediately afterwards was a time of massive [[cultural assimilation|assimilation]] to the local culture (for example during the [[Getúlio Vargas]] period in [[Brazil]]). Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Paraguay show some clear demographic differences that affect the minority situation of the German language: Brazil and Argentina are massive countries and offer large amounts of land for immigrants to settle. The population density of the [[Southern Cone]] countries is relatively low (Brazil has 17 inhabitants/km², Chile has 15/km², Argentina and Paraguay both have 10/km², data from 1993), but there are major differences in the areas settled by Germans: [[Buenos Aires Province]], which was settled by [[Germans]], has a far higher population density than that of the [[Chaco Department|Chaco]] in northern Paraguay (with 1 inhabitant/km²). Argentina and Chile have a far greater proportion of city dwellers (86% and 84% respectively), while Brazil is 82% urbanised, and Paraguay is just 47% urbanised. Most of the German immigrants that arrived in Brazil went on to live in small inland communities. The original 58 German communities of the early 19th century Brazil, grew today to over 250 towns where Germans are a majority, and German speaking is encouraged. ===Argentina=== {{further|Argentinien-schwyzertütsch dialect|German Argentine}} There are about 500,000 German speakers and around 320,000 Volga-Germans alone, of which 200,000 hold German citizenship. This makes Argentina one of the countries with the largest number of German speakers and is second only in Latin America to Brazil. In the 1930s there were about 700,000 people of German descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.tau.ac.il/eial/VI_2/gaudig_veit.htm|title=Estudios Interdisciplinarios de América Latina y el Caribe|website=www.tau.ac.il|accessdate=4 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130613124722/http://www.tau.ac.il/eial/VI_2/gaudig_veit.htm|archivedate=13 June 2013|df=}} Regional concentrations can be found in the provinces of [[Entre Ríos Province|Entre Ríos]] and [[Buenos Aires]] (with around 500,000 to 600,000) as well as [[Misiones Province|Misiones]] and in the general area of the Chaco and the [[Pampas]]. However most German-descended Argentinians do not speak German with native fluency (that role has been taken by Spanish). The 300,000 German speakers are estimated to be immigrants and not actually born in Argentina, and because of this they still speak their home language while their descendants who were born in Argentina speak primarily Spanish. ===Brazil=== {{Main|Brazilian German}} According to [[Deutsche Welle]], there are some twelve million people of German ancestry in Brazil. Nevertheless, the number of people speaking any sort of German (Standard German, [[Hunsrückisch dialect|Hunsrückisch]] or [[East Pomeranian dialect|East Pomeranian]]) is on the decrease, with 3 million speaking German as a first language today. The main variety of German in Brazil is [[Riograndenser Hunsrückisch]] which is to be found in the southern states. This version of German there has changed over 180 years of contact with Portuguese as well as the [[Talian dialect|languages of other immigrant communities]]. Such contact has led to a new dialect of German concentrated in the German colonies in the southern province of [[Rio Grande do Sul]]. Although Riograndenser Hunsrückisch has long been the most widely spoken German dialect in southern Brazil, like all other minority languages in the region, it is experiencing very strong decline - especially in the last three or four decades. In all the vast majority of German descended Brazilians speaks Portuguese as their mother tongue today, and German is known only as a second or third language, if at all, to the point of initiatives to preserve the language being started recently in areas with strong German-descended presence, with government sponsored Gemeindeschulen. This is especially true for younger German-Brazilians. Another place where the German language continues alive is in some of the more of four thousand Brazilian Lutheran churches, in which some of the cults continue to be in German.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,1564,1174391,00.html|title=O alemão lusitano do Sul do Brasil - Cultura - DW - 20.04.2004|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(www.dw.com)|website=DW.COM|accessdate=4 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513192441/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,1564,1174391,00.html|archivedate=13 May 2011|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/language/hrx|title=Hunsrückish|publisher=Ethnologue|accessdate=20 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707172737/http://www.ethnologue.com/language/hrx|archivedate=7 July 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/country/BR|title=Standard German|publisher=Ethnologue|accessdate=20 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150708114057/http://www.ethnologue.com/country/BR|archivedate=8 July 2015|df=}} ===Chile=== Chile (with a population of 15 million) has an estimated 40,000 German-speakers.[http://www.bpb.de/wissen/08937231579775312662617270950640,1,0,Auslandsdeutsche.html#art1 Handwörterbuch des politischen Systems der Bundesrepublik] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310000000/http://www.bpb.de/wissen/08937231579775312662617270950640,1,0,Auslandsdeutsche.html#art1 |date=March 10, 2011 }} {{de icon}}. About 30,000 ethnic Germans arrived in Chile. During the first flux of German immigration (between 1846 and 1875) German colonies were primarily set up in the "Frontera" region. The second wave of immigration occurred between 1882 and 1914 and consisted mainly of industrial and agricultural workers, mainly from eastern Germany; the third wave (after 1918) settled mainly in the cities. As in Argentina and Brazil, these populations are today overwhelmingly Spanish speaking, and German as a home language is in heavy decline. ===Colombia=== Colombia has a population of about 40 million people. Of the 40 million only 5,000 people of German descent speak the language. Many of these people settled in Antioquia, and el Eje Cafetero. Most of the immigration occurred during World War I until the end of the Cold War. Many of these ethnic Germans now speak primarily Spanish at home. Germans came to South America in the world wars I and II, settling first in Colombia because of its wealth in natural resources and favourable weather conditions for agriculture. German immigrants built the Bavaria, Pilsen, Club soda Klausen factories in Cali, Barranquilla, Pereira, Medellin, and other cities. Germans born in Colombia celebrate Oktoberfest in Cali along with other traditions. There are currently German schools in various major cities around the country. ===Costa Rica=== Costa Rica has a population of 4.8 million, and a German speaker population of 8,000 people. Many of these people are immigrants or native German speakers from Germany or Switzerland and 18th, 19th and 20th centuries massive immigration descendants. But also in the northern area of the country, there are 2,200 German Mennonites communities in Sarapiquí and San Carlos that spoke Plautdietsch and other Low German dialects. This German-Costa Rican community is one of the most important and biggest collectivities of German speakers in Central America and the Caribbean, and has a lot of cultural and social institutions, churches, farms, business companies and schools. == North America == ===Canada=== In [[Canada]], there are 622,650 speakers of German according to the most recent census in 2006,{{cite web |url=http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/topics/RetrieveProductTable.cfm?ALEVEL=3&APATH=3&CATNO=&DETAIL=0&DIM=&DS=99&FL=0&FREE=0&GAL=0&GC=99&GK=NA&GRP=1&IPS=&METH=0&ORDER=1&PID=89189&PTYPE=88971&RL=0&S=1&ShowAll=No&StartRow=1&SUB=705&Temporal=2006&Theme=70&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF=&GID=837928 |title=Statistics Canada 2006 |publisher=2.statcan.ca |date=6 January 2010 |accessdate=15 March 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090818230831/http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/topics/RetrieveProductTable.cfm?ALEVEL=3&APATH=3&CATNO=&DETAIL=0&DIM=&DS=99&FL=0&FREE=0&GAL=0&GC=99&GK=NA&GRP=1&IPS=&METH=0&ORDER=1&PID=89189&PTYPE=88971&RL=0&S=1&ShowAll=No&StartRow=1&SUB=705&Temporal=2006&Theme=70&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF=&GID=837928 |archivedate=18 August 2009 |df= }} with people of German ancestry ([[German Canadians]]) found throughout the country. German-speaking communities are particularly found in [[British Columbia]] (118,035) and [[Ontario]] (230,330). There is a large and vibrant community in the city of [[Kitchener, Ontario]], which was at one point named Berlin. German immigrants were instrumental in the country's three largest urban areas: [[Montreal]], [[Toronto]], and [[Vancouver]]; post-[[Second World War]] immigrants managed to preserve a fluency in the German language in their respective neighborhoods and sections. In the first half of the 20th century, over a million [[German-Canadian]]s made the language Canada's third most spoken after [[French language|French]] and [[English language|English]]. ===Mexico=== In Mexico there are also large populations of [[German Mexican|German ancestry]], mainly in the cities of: [[Mexico City]],''Tools of Progress: A German Merchant Family in Mexico City, 1865–present'' {{ISBN|978-0-826-33087-1}} pp. ix-8 [[Puebla]], [[Mazatlán]], [[Tapachula]], [[Ecatepec de Morelos]], and larger populations scattered in the states of [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Durango]], and [[Zacatecas]].''[https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowTopic-g150792-i257-k3377754-How_German_is_Mazatlan-Mazatlan_Pacific_Coast.html How German is Mazatlan?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119175435/https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowTopic-g150792-i257-k3377754-How_German_is_Mazatlan-Mazatlan_Pacific_Coast.html |date=2018-01-19 }}'', tripadvisor.co.uk''Concise Encyclopedia of Amish, Brethren, Hutterites, and Mennonites'' {{ISBN|978-0-801-89657-6}} p. 144 ===United States=== {{Main|German language in the United States|Pennsylvania German language|Plautdietsch|Hutterite German}} In the United States, the states of [[North Dakota]] and [[South Dakota]] are the only states where German is the most common language spoken at home after English.{{cite web |url=https://www.census.gov/population/cen2000/phc-t20/tab05.pdf |title=Table 5. Detailed List of Languages Spoken at Home for the Population 5 Years and Over by State: 2000 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=15 March 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117052130/http://www.census.gov/population/cen2000/phc-t20/tab05.pdf |archivedate=17 January 2010 |df= }} German geographical names can be found throughout the Midwest region of the country, such as [[New Ulm, Minnesota|New Ulm]] and many other towns in [[Minnesota]]; [[Bismarck, North Dakota|Bismarck]] (North Dakota's state capital), [[Munich, North Dakota|Munich]], [[Karlsruhe, North Dakota|Karlsruhe]], and [[Strasburg, North Dakota|Strasburg]] (named after a town near Odessa in Ukraine){{cite web |url=https://library.ndsu.edu/grhc/order/nd_sd/strasburg.html |title=Germans from Russia Heritage Collection |website=Library.ndsu.edu |date= |accessdate=18 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818163048/https://library.ndsu.edu/grhc/order/nd_sd/strasburg.html |archivedate=18 August 2016 |df= }} in North Dakota; [[New Braunfels]], [[Fredericksburg, Texas|Fredericksburg]], Weimar, and [[Muenster, Texas|Muenster]] in Texas; Corn (formerly Korn), Kiefer and Berlin in Oklahoma; and [[Kiel, Wisconsin|Kiel]], [[Berlin, Wisconsin|Berlin]], and [[Germantown, Wisconsin|Germantown]] in Wisconsin. Between 1843 and 1910, more than 5 million Germans emigrated overseas,Henry Steele Commager (1961). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Czlg39-Z75kC&pg=PA102&dq&hl=en#v=onepage&q=&f=false Immigration and American history: essays in honor of Theodore C. Blegen]''. University of Minnesota Press. p.102. {{ISBN|0-8166-5735-1}} mostly to the United States.49.2 million [[German Americans]] as of 2005 according to the {{cite web|url=http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/IPTable?_bm=y&-reg=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201:535;ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201PR:535;ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201T:535;ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201TPR:535&-qr_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201&-qr_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201PR&-qr_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201T&-qr_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201TPR&-ds_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_&-TABLE_NAMEX=&-ci_type=A&-redoLog=false&-charIterations=047&-geo_id=01000US&-format=&-_lang=en |author=United States Census Bureau |title=US demographic census |accessdate=2 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124114349/http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/IPTable?_bm=y&-reg=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201%3A535%3BACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201PR%3A535%3BACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201T%3A535%3BACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201TPR%3A535&-qr_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201&-qr_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201PR&-qr_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201T&-qr_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_S0201TPR&-ds_name=ACS_2005_EST_G00_&-TABLE_NAMEX=&-ci_type=A&-redoLog=false&-charIterations=047&-geo_id=01000US&-format=&-_lang=en |archivedate=24 November 2011 |df=dmy }}; the 1990 census gives 57.9 million, or 23.3% of the U.S. population. German remained an important language in churches, schools, newspapers, and even the administration of the [[United States Brewers' Association]]{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HhQZAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22United%20States%20Brewers'%20Association%22%20reports%20of%20proceedings&pg=PA118#v=onepage&q=german&f=false|title=Documentary History of the United States Brewers' Association|publisher=}} through the early 20th century, but was severely repressed during [[World War I]]. Over the course of the 20th century, many of the descendants of 18th century and 19th century immigrants ceased speaking German at home, but small populations of speakers are still found in [[Pennsylvania]] ([[Amish]], [[Hutterites]], [[Dunkard Township, Greene County, Pennsylvania|Dunkards]] and some [[Mennonites]] historically spoke [[Hutterite German]] and a [[West Central German]] variety of German known as [[Pennsylvania German language|Pennsylvania German]] or Pennsylvania Dutch), [[Kansas]] (Mennonites and [[Volga German]]s), North Dakota (Hutterite Germans, Mennonites, [[History of Germans in Russia and the Soviet Union|Russian Germans]], Volga Germans, and [[Baltic Germans]]), [[South Dakota]], [[Montana]], [[Texas]] ([[Texas German]]), [[Wisconsin]], [[Indiana]], [[Oregon]], [[Oklahoma]], and [[Ohio]] (72,570).{{cite web|url=http://www.mla.org/cgi-shl/docstudio/docs.pl?map_data_results |title=Archived copy |accessdate=10 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130815140430/http://www.mla.org/cgi-shl/docstudio/docs.pl?map_data_results |archivedate=15 August 2013 |df=dmy }}{{citation needed|date=January 2018|reason=Given citation does not provide any useful information}} A significant group of German [[Pietists]] in [[Iowa]] formed the [[Amana Colonies]] and continue to practice speaking their heritage language. Early twentieth century immigration was often to [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Chicago]], [[New York City|New York]], [[Milwaukee]], [[Pittsburgh]] and [[Cincinnati]]. [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 137-005795, Deutsche Zeitungen in Nordamerika.jpg|thumb|[[German in the United States#German-language press|German-language newspapers in the U.S.]] in 1922]] The dialects of German which are or were primarily spoken in colonies or communities founded by German-speaking people resemble the dialects of the regions the founders came from. For example, Hutterite German resembles dialects of [[Carinthia (state)|Carinthia]]. [[Texas German]] is a dialect spoken in the areas of Texas settled by the [[Adelsverein]], such as New Braunfels and Fredericksburg. In the [[Amana Colonies]] in the state of Iowa, [[Amana German]] is spoken. [[Plautdietsch]] is a large [[minority language]] spoken in Northern Mexico by the [[Mennonite]] communities, and is spoken by more than 200,000 people in Mexico. [[Pennsylvania German language|Pennsylvania German]] is a [[West Central German]] dialect spoken by most of the [[Amish]] population of Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Indiana and resembles [[Palatine German language|Palatinate German]] dialects. {{Citation needed|date=June 2017}} [[Hutterite German]] is an Upper German dialect of the [[Austro-Bavarian]] variety of the German language, which is spoken by Hutterite communities in Canada and the United States. Hutterite is spoken in the U.S. states of [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Montana]], [[North Dakota]], [[South Dakota]], and [[Minnesota]]; and in the Canadian provinces of [[Alberta]], [[Saskatchewan]] and [[Manitoba]]. Its speakers belong to some Schmiedleit, Lehrerleit, and Dariusleit Hutterite groups, but there are also speakers among the older generations of Prairieleit (the descendants of those Hutterites who chose not to settle in colonies). Hutterite children who grow up in the colonies learn to speak Hutterite German before learning English, the standard language of the surrounding areas, in school. Many of these children, though, continue with German Grammar School, in addition to public school, throughout a student's elementary education.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} ==Rest of the world== Minorities exist in the countries of the former [[Soviet Union]], [[Poland]], [[Romania]], [[Hungary]], the [[Czech Republic]], [[Denmark]], [[France]], [[Belgium]], [[Italy]], [[Canada]], [[Chile]], the [[United States]], [[Latin America]], [[Namibia]], [[South Africa]], [[Israel]], and [[Australia]]. These German minorities, through their [[ethno-cultural]] vitality, exhibit an exceptional level of heterogeneity: variations concerning their [[demographics]], their status within the majority community, the support they receive from institutions helping them to support their identity as a minority. Among them are small groups (such as those in Namibia) and many very large groups (such as the almost 1 million non-evacuated Germans in Russia and [[Kazakhstan]] or the near 500,000 Germans in [[Brazil]] (see [[Riograndenser Hunsrückisch German]])), groups that have been greatly "folklorised" and almost completely linguistically assimilated (such as most people of German descent in the US, Canada, Australia, Argentina and Brazil), and others, such as the true linguistic minorities (like the still German-speaking minorities in the US, [[Argentina]] and Brazil, in western [[Siberia]] or in Romania and Hungary); other groups, which are classified as [[religio-cultural]] groups rather than ethnic minorities, (such as the Eastern-Low German speaking [[Mennonites]] in [[Paraguay]], [[Mexico]], [[Belize]] or in the [[Altay Mountains|Altay]] region of [[Siberia]]) and the groups who maintain their status thanks to strong identification with their ethnicity and their religious sentiment (such as the groups in [[Upper Silesia]], [[Poland]] or in South [[Jutland]] in [[Denmark]]). ==See also== {{Portal|Languages}} * [[List of territorial entities where German is an official language]] * [[Ethnic German]] * [[German diaspora#Distribution]] * [[Germanic languages]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== ==External links== * [https://www.goethe.de/resources/files/pdf19/5759818-STANDARD.pdf German language studying in the world in 2010 (with evolution from 2005)] * [https://www.goethe.de/resources/files/pdf19/1459127-STANDARD1.pdf German language studying in the world in 2005 (with evolution from 2000)] * [https://www.goethe.de/resources/files/pdf19/StADaF_DE_2012.pdf German language in the world in 2012 (full report)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060528172249/http://www.kuwi.euv-frankfurt-o.de/~sw1www/publikation/lateinam.htm Development of German in South America] {{de icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050415020802/http://viadrina.euv-frankfurt-o.de/~sw1www/publikation/lateinam.htm Deutsche Minderheiten/Riograndenser Hunsrückisch] {{de icon}} {{Geographical distribution of languages}} [[Category:Geographical distribution of the German language| ]] [[Category:Linguistic minorities]] [[Category:Second-language acquisition|German]] [[Category:Language geography|German]]

He won [[Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play]] in 1966 for his portrayal of Twain. Throughout his career, he won five [[Primetime Emmy Awards]]. Holbrook made his film debut in [[Sidney Lumet]]'s ''[[The Group (film)|The Group]]'' (1966). He later gained international fame for his performance as [[Deep Throat (Watergate)|Deep Throat]] in the 1976 film ''[[All the President's Men (film)|All the President's Men]]''. He played [[Abraham Lincoln]] in the 1976 miniseries ''Lincoln''. He has also appeared in such films as ''[[Julia (1977 film)|Julia]]'' (1977), ''[[The Fog]]'' (1980), ''[[Creepshow]]'' (1982), ''[[Wall Street (1987 film)|Wall Street]]'' (1987), ''[[The Firm (1993 film)|The Firm]]'' (1993), ''[[Hercules (1997 film)|Hercules]]'' (1997), and ''[[Men of Honor]]'' (2000).{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/filmgrph/hal_holbrook.htm|title=Hal Holbrook Filmography|publisher=[[Washington Post]]|accessdate=January 25, 2017}} Holbrook's role as Ron Franz in [[Sean Penn]]'s ''[[Into the Wild (film)|Into the Wild]]'' (2007) earned him both [[Screen Actors Guild Award]] and [[Academy Award]] nominations for Best Supporting Actor. Until [[Robert Duvall]] was nominated for an Academy Award in 2015, Holbrook was the oldest actor to receive a [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]] nomination.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/oscars-robert-duvall-becomes-oldest-supporting-actor-nominee-050005183.html|title=Oscars: Robert Duvall Becomes Oldest Supporting Actor Nominee Ever|date=January 15, 2015|work=Yahoo News}} In 2009, Holbrook received critical acclaim for his performance as recently retired farmer, Abner Meecham, in the independent film ''[[That Evening Sun (film)|That Evening Sun]]''. In his later career, Holbrook appeared as [[Francis Preston Blair]] in [[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[Lincoln (film)|Lincoln]]'' (2012), provided his voice as Mayday in the [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]] animated film ''[[Planes: Fire & Rescue]]'' (2014) and as Whizzer in ''[[Blackway]]'' (2015).{{cite web |url= https://tv.yahoo.com/news/first-look-photo-anthony-hopkins-074049980.html |title= First-Look Photo: Anthony Hopkins in 'Go With Me' – Berlin |publisher=[[Yahoo]].com |accessdate= February 9, 2015}} As a television actor, Holbrook is known for starring in and directing four episodes in ''[[Designing Women]]'' as Reese Watson, opposite his wife, [[Dixie Carter]]. Later in his career, he has starred in minor roles in ''[[Sons of Anarchy]]'', ''[[The Event (TV series)|The Event]]'', and ''[[Rectify (TV series)|Rectify]]''. He has guest-starred in many critically acclaimed television series such as ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'', ''[[The West Wing]]'', ''[[The Sopranos]]'', ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'', ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'', and ''[[Hawaii Five-0 (2010 TV series)|Hawaii Five-0]]''. In 2003, Holbrook was honored with the [[National Humanities Medal]] by President [[George W. Bush]]. ==Early life== Holbrook was born in [[Cleveland|Cleveland, Ohio]], the son of Aileen (née Davenport) Holbrook (1905–1987), a [[vaudeville]] dancer, and Harold Rowe Holbrook Sr. (1902–1982).{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/0/Hal-Holbrook.html|title=Hal Holbrook profile|publisher=Film Reference.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} After being abandoned by his parents at age two, along with his two older sisters, they were raised by his paternal grandparents, first in [[Weymouth, Massachusetts]], and later in the Cleveland suburb of [[Lakewood, Ohio|Lakewood]].{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-laff-hal-holbrook-american-odyssey-20140614-story.html|title='American Odyssey' chronicles 60 years of Hal Holbrook as Mark Twain|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=March 12, 2017|date=June 13, 2014|author=Susan King}} He graduated from Culver Military Academy, now part of the [[Culver Academies]], and then from [[Denison University]], where an honors project about Mark Twain led him to develop the [[one-man show]] for which he is best known, a series of performances called ''Mark Twain Tonight''.{{cite web|title=Hal Holbrook at the Internet Broadway Database|work=Awards|url=http://www.ibdb.com/awardperson.asp?id=15128|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208112329/http://www.ibdb.com/awardperson.asp?id=15128|archivedate=2008-12-08}} From 1942-46, Holbrook served in the [[United States Army]] in [[World War II]] under the ranks of [[Staff sergeant#United States|staff sergeant]] and was stationed in [[Dominion of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]].{{cite web|url=http://army.togetherweserved.com/army/servlet/tws.webapp.WebApps?cmd=ShadowBoxProfile&type=Person&ID=344577|title=Holbrook, Harold Rowe, Jr., S/Sgt Assisted|publisher=TogetherWeServed.com|accessdate= January 25, 2017}} While stationed in Newfoundland, he performed in theater productions such as the play ''Madam Precious''. ==Career== Holbrook's first solo performance as Twain was at [[Lock Haven University of Pennsylvania|Lock Haven State Teachers College]] in Pennsylvania in 1954. [[Ed Sullivan]] saw him and gave Holbrook his first national exposure on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' on February 12, 1956. Holbrook was also a member of the Valley Players (1941–1962), a summer-stock theater company based in [[Holyoke, Massachusetts]], which performed at Mountain Park Casino Playhouse at Mountain Park. He joined The Lamns in 1955, where he began developing his one-man show. He was a member of the cast for several years and performed ''Mark Twain Tonight'' as the 1957 season opener.{{cite web |url=http://holyokehistory.blogspot.com/ |title= Holyoke History Room & Archives '''Valley Players Collection (1941-1993)'''. HPLA2007.527 |publisher= Holyokehistory.com |accessdate= April 12, 2015}} The [[United States Department of State|State Department]] even sent him on a European tour, which included pioneering appearances behind the [[Iron Curtain]]. In 1959, Holbrook first played the role [[off-Broadway]]. [[Columbia Records]] recorded an LP of excerpts from the show. [[File:The Brighter Day Scene 1954.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Holbrook in ''The Brighter Day Scene'', August 1954]] Holbrook performed in a special production for the [[1964 New York World's Fair|New York World's Fair (1964, 1965)]] for the Bell Telephone Pavilion.{{cite web|url=http://www.westland.net/ny64fair/map-docs/technology.htm|title=New York World's Fair '64|publisher=Westland.net|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} Jo Mielziner created an innovative audio-visual ride experience and used Holbrook's acting talents on 65 different action screens for "The Ride Of Communications" with the movie itself known as ''From Drumbeats to Telstar''. [[File:Mark Twain by AF Bradley.jpg|thumb|left|180px|[[Mark Twain]] would serve as an inspiration to Holbrook's early and eventual entire career through his performance as Twain in ''[[Mark Twain Tonight]]'']] In 1967, ''Mark Twain Tonight'' was presented on television by [[CBS]] and [[Xerox]], and Holbrook received an [[Emmy]] for his performance. Holbrook's Twain first played on Broadway in 1966, and again in 1977 and 2005; Holbrook was 80 years old during his most recent Broadway run, older (for the first time) than the character he was portraying. Holbrook won a Tony Award for the performance in 1966. Until Holbrook retired in 2017, aged 92, ''Mark Twain Tonight'' toured the country, which amounted to over about 2100 performances. He has portrayed Twain longer than [[Samuel Langhorne Clemens]] did.{{cite news|title=Mark Twain. Now a Career for the Mustachioed|newspaper=New York Times|date=January 24, 2011|author=Malia Wollan|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/24/books/24twain.html|quote=...has played Twain going on 57 years, longer than Samuel Langhorne Clemens did.}} In 1964, Holbrook played the role of the Major in the original production of [[Arthur Miller]]'s ''[[Incident at Vichy]]''. In 1968, he was one of the replacements for [[Richard Kiley]] in the original [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of ''[[Man of La Mancha]]'', although he had limited singing ability.{{cite web|url=http://www.masterworksbroadway.com/artist/hal-holbrook|title=Hal Holbrook|publisher=Master Works Broadway.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} In 1966, Holbrook starred opposite [[Shirley Booth]] in the acclaimed CBS Playhouse production of ''The Glass Menagerie''.{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/a-lost-glass-menagerie-rediscovered|title=A Lost "Glass Menagerie" Rediscovered|author=Michael Shaulman|date=December 7, 2016|accessdate=September 16, 2017|work=[[The New Yorker]]}} Holbrook co-starred with [[Martin Sheen]] in the controversial and acclaimed 1972 [[television film]] ''[[That Certain Summer]]''. In 1973, Holbrook appeared as Lieutenant Neil Briggs, the boss and rival of Detective [[Harry Callahan (character)|Harry Callahan]] ([[Clint Eastwood]]) in ''[[Magnum Force]]'', an "obsessively neat and prim fanatic" who supports the obliteration of San Francisco's criminals and who is the leader of a rogue group of vigilante officers.{{cite book|last=Baker|first=Brian|title=Masculinity in Fiction and Film: Representing Men in Popular Genres, 1945-2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K3iYZjnLfXcC&pg=PA104|accessdate=18 February 2013|date=9 April 2006|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-84714-149-1|page=104}}{{cite book|last=Brunsdale|first=Mitzi M.|title=Icons of Mystery and Crime Detection: From Sleuths to Superheroes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p2zTtMxkExgC&pg=PA368|accessdate=18 February 2013|date=26 July 2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-34530-2|page=368}} In 1976, Holbrook won acclaim for his portrayal of [[Abraham Lincoln]] in a series of television specials based on [[Carl Sandburg]]'s acclaimed biography. He won a [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series]] for the 1970 series ''[[The Bold Ones: The Senator]]''. In 1979, he starred with [[Katharine Ross]], [[Barry Bostwick]], and [[Richard Anderson]] in the made-for-TV movie ''[[Murder by Natural Causes]]''. Holbrook also had a major role on the sitcom ''[[Evening Shade]]'' throughout its entire run. Early in his career, Holbrook worked onstage and in a television soap opera, ''[[The Brighter Day]]''. He is also famous for his role as the enigmatic [[Deep Throat (Watergate)|Deep Throat]] (whose identity was unknown at the time) in the film ''[[All the President's Men (film)|All the President's Men]]''.{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/movies/features/11932|title=Deep Throat is W. Mark Felt. And Hal Holbrook. And Kirsten Dunst. And . . .|publisher=New York Magazine.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/hal-holbrook/credits/152905/|title=Hal Holbrook List of Movies and TV Shows|publisher=[[TV Guide]]|accessdate=January 27, 2017}} Holbrook was the narrator on the [[Ken Burns]] documentary ''[[Lewis & Clark: The Journey of the Corps of Discovery]]'' in 1997. [[File:Hal Holbrook as Mark Twain.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Holbrook performing as Twain at the [[University of Houston]]]] From 1986-89, Holbrook had a recurring role as Reese Watson on ''[[Designing Women]]'', opposite his wife [[Dixie Carter]]. For a short period between 1988 and 1990, Holbrook directed four episodes of the series. In 1999, Holbrook was inducted into the [[American Theatre Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|url=http://old.post-gazette.com/magazine/19991117rawson5.asp|title=On Stage: New class of theater hall of famers}} In 2000, Holbrook appeared in'' [[Men of Honor]]'', where he portrayed a racist and hypocritical officer who endlessly tries to fail an African-American diver trainee.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/214076/Men-of-Honor/overview|title=Men of Honor (2000)|publisher=The New York Times.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} He appeared in [[Sean Penn]]'s critically acclaimed film ''Into the Wild'' (2007) and received an [[Academy Award|Oscar]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role]] at the [[80th Academy Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/02/21/hal.holbrook/index.html|title=Veteran actor Hal Holbrook's loving his Oscar nod|publisher=CNN.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} At the time, this rendered Holbrook, at age 82, the oldest nominee in Academy Award history in the Best Supporting Actor category. On December 20, 2007, Holbrook was nominated for a [[Screen Actors Guild Award]] for his work in the film. In late August through mid-September 2007, he starred as the narrator in the Hartford Stage production of [[Thornton Wilder]]'s ''[[Our Town]]'', a role he had once played on television. In 2003, President [[George W. Bush]] honored Holbrook with a [[National Humanities Medal]] for "charming audiences with the wit and wisdom of Mark Twain as Twain's outlook never fails to give Holbrook a good show to put on".{{cite web|url=https://www.neh.gov/about/awards/national-humanities-medals/hal-holbrook|title=Hal Holbrook|publisher=[[National Endowment for the Humanities]]|accessdate=March 12, 2017|date=November 1, 2003}} [[File:Hal Holbrook LF.jpg|thumb|left|160px|Holbrook in December 2009]] Holbrook appeared with wife Dixie Carter in ''That Evening Sun'', filmed in East Tennessee in the summer of 2008. The film, produced by Dogwood Entertainment, is based on a short story by [[William Gay (author)|William Gay]]. ''That Evening Sun'' premiered in March 2009 at [[South By Southwest]], where it received the Audience Award for Narrative Feature and a special Jury Prize for Ensemble Cast. [[Joe Leydon]] of [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']] hailed Hollbrook's performance in the film as a "career-highlight star turn as an irascible octogenarian farmer who will not go gentle into that good night."{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117939947.html?categoryid=31&cs=1|title=That Evening Sun|publisher= Variety|accessdate=March 26, 2009}} ''That Evening Sun'' also was screened at the 2009 [[Nashville Film Festival]], where Holbrook was honored with a special Lifetime Achievement Award, and the film itself received another Audience Award.{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/nashvillefilmfestival/2009/prweb2357044.htm|title=Nashville Film Festival|publisher=PR Web.com|accessdate=April 24, 2009}} [[File:Hal Holbrook receives the National Humanities Medal Award (cropped) 02.jpg|thumb|President [[George W. Bush]] and [[Laura Bush]] pose for a photo with Holbrook (center), a recipient of the [[National Humanities Medal]] in the [[Oval Office]] on November 14, 2003]] Holbrook appeared as a featured guest star in a 2006 episode of the [[HBO]] series ''[[The Sopranos]]'' and the ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'' episode "Escaped". On April 22, 2010, Holbrook signed on to portray [[Katey Sagal]]'s character's father on the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] original series'' [[Sons of Anarchy]]'' for a four-episode arc in their third season, as well as appearing in additional fifth episode in the final season.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/television/Hal-Holbrook-Joins-Sons-of-Anarchy-24166.html|title=Hal Holbrook Joins Sons of Anarchy|publisher=Cinemablend.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} He also had a multiple-episode arc on ''[[The Event]]'', an American television series on [[NBC]], appearing in the 2010–2011 season. In 2011, Holbrook appeared in ''[[Water for Elephants (film)|Water for Elephants]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/blogs/popcornbiz/_Water_for_Elephants__All__National_-111998149.html|title=Hal Holbrook Totally Owns the "Water for Elephants" Trailer|publisher=NBC New York.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} In 2012, [[Steven Spielberg]] cast Holbrook to play [[Francis Preston Blair]] in ''[[Lincoln (film)|Lincoln]]''.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/dec/16/entertainment/la-et-mn-hal-holbrook-classic-hollywood-20121217|title=Hal Holbrook is always up for challenging fare|publisher=LA Times.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} His recent films are [[Gus Van Sant]]'s ''[[Promised Land (2012 film)|Promised Land]]'' (2012),{{Cite news|last=Gerhardt|first=Tina|date=December 31, 2012|title=Matt Damon Exposes Fracking in Promised Land|url=http://www.progressive.org/matt-damon-exposes-fracking-in-promised-land|work=[[The Progressive]]}} the animated film ''Planes: Fire & Rescue'' (2014),{{cite web|url=http://www.movieweb.com/movie/planes-fire-rescue/hal-holbrook-interview|title='Planes: Fire & Rescue' Interview with Hal Holbrook|publisher=Movie Web.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} and in the minor role as Whizzer in the drama film ''[[Blackway]]'' (2016). In 2014, Holbrook was the subject of Scott Teems' documentary ''Holbrook/Twain: An American Odyssey'' depicting Holbrook's long lasting career as portraying Twain. It was premiered at the [[Los Angeles Film Festival]] that same year. In 2016, Holbrook was cast as Red Hudmore and appeared in the [[Bones (season 12)|final season]] of ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'' on January 17, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2016/08/16/bones-season-12-episode-3-cast-ed-asner-hal-holbrook/|title=Bones Enlists Acting Vets Ed Asner and Hal Holbrook for Final Season|publisher=TVLine.com|accessdate=January 27, 2017|date=August 16, 2016|author=Michael Ausiello}} On March 23, 2017, aged 92, he appeared on an episode on ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'' playing a retired thoracic surgeon whose wife is a patient, and on ''[[Hawaii Five-0 (2010 TV series)|Hawaii Five-0]]'' later in the year.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/greys-anatomy-guest-stars-june-squibb-and-hal-holbrook-1201999499/|title=June Squibb and Hal Holbrook to Guest Star on 'Grey's Anatomy' (EXCLUSIVE)|author=Elisabeth Wagmeiser|date=March 1, 2017|accessdate=March 1, 2017|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/hawaii-five-0-spoilers-hal-holbrook/|title=Exclusive: Hawaii Five-0 Enlists Hal Holbrook to Guest-Star|publisher=TV Guide|accessdate=March 12, 2017|date=March 7, 2017}} In September 2017, after six decades of playing the role of [[Mark Twain]], Holbrook announced his retirement from the one-man show ''[[Mark Twain Tonight|Mark Twain Tonight!]]''{{Cite news|url=http://newsok.com/article/5563884|title=Hal Holbrook retires his award-winning one-man show 'Mark Twain Tonight!' after 63 years, cancels Oklahoma City performance|date=2017-09-13|work=NewsOK.com|access-date=2017-09-14}} Holbrook indicated that he would like to continue working on movies and television. ==Personal life== Holbrook has been married three times and has three children. He married a Canadian, Ruby Elaine Johnstone (born August 28, 1923; later known as actress '''Ruby Holbrook''') on September 22, 1945, and they had two children, Victoria Rowe Holbrook and David Vining Holbrook. They divorced in 1965, and on December 28, 1966, he married Carol Eve Rossen. They had one child, Eve Holbrook, and they divorced on June 14, 1983.{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/hal-holbrook-267542|title=Hal Holbrook|publisher=Biography.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} [[Image:Hal Holbrook and Dixie Carter at the 41st Emmy Awards.jpg|thumb|right|Holbrook and Carter at the [[41st Primetime Emmy Awards]], 1990]] He married actress and singer [[Dixie Carter]] on May 27, 1984; the couple remained married until Carter's death from [[endometrial cancer]] on April 10, 2010 (aged 70).{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/12/arts/television/12carter.html|title=Dixie Carter, Star of TV's 'Designing Women', Dies at 70|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=October 24, 2018|date=April 11, 2010}} Architect Hoyte Johnson of [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] redesigned Carter's [[Tennessee]] family home and created an environment that the couple shared with family and friends.{{cite web|url=http://www.carrollcounty-tn-chamber.com/hal_dixie.htm|title=Hal & Dixie|publisher=Carroll County Chamber.com|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} Holbrook said the home has the "feel" of the Mark Twain House in [[Hartford, Connecticut]], and that there is no other place to which he feels so ideally suited.{{IMDb name|1358|section=bio}} Holbrook had a recurring role on his wife's hit sitcom ''Designing Women,'' appearing in nine episodes between 1986 and 1989 as Carter's on-screen significant other. In 2011, Holbrook's memoir, ''Harold: The Boy Who Became Mark Twain'', was published by [[Farrar, Straus and Giroux]].{{cite web|url=http://us.macmillan.com/haroldtheboywhobecamemarktwain/halholbrook/9780374533595|title=Harold: The Boy Who Became Mark Twain|publisher=US MacMillan|accessdate=January 28, 2017}} In October 2016, Holbrook wrote a letter to ''[[The New York Times]]'' defending actor-director [[Nate Parker]] over his alleged 1991 rape of a woman and Parker's controversial film ''[[The Birth of a Nation (2016 film)|The Birth of a Nation]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/15/opinion/hal-holbrook-on-the-birth-of-a-nation.html|title=Hal Holbrook, on 'The Birth of a Nation'|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|author=Hal Holbrook|date=October 14, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2017}} He urged others to "move on" from Parker's past and to view the film which was "an exceptional piece of artistry and a vital portrait of our American experience". Holbrook has occasionally criticized the politicization of religion.{{cite web|url=http://www.postcrescent.com/story/entertainment/2015/04/22/hal-holbrook-bringing-mark-twain-fox-cities-pac-ready-vent/26189965|title=Hal Holbrook, bringing 'Mark Twain' to PAC, is ready to vent|publisher=Postcresent.com|accessdate=May 10, 2015}} He is a registered [[Independent (United States)|independent]], but leans towards the liberal end of the political spectrum. He criticized the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] while [[Barack Obama]] was in office.{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2010/05/hal-holbrook-speaks-out-against-republican-party-leaders.html|title=Hal Holbrook Speaks Out Against Republican Party Leaders|publisher=[[LA Times]].com|accessdate=May 10, 2015}} In 2016, he castigated then-Republican-candidate [[Donald Trump]] for not having "the maturity to run the country".{{cite web|url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/entertainment/arts-culture/article53162400.html|title=Hal Holbrook channels Mark Twain on stage|publisher=San Luis Obispo.com|accessdate=January 25, 2017|date=January 5, 2016|author=Patrick S. Pemberton}} Holbrook praised Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] as the only politician who does not "say what they think might get them elected" and praised his honesty.{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-hal-holbrook-wants-keep-863873|title=Why Hal Holbrook Wants to Keep Touring With 'Mark Twain Tonight'|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=October 23, 2018}} In 2017, Holbrook again criticized President Trump, saying, "We have [Trump] who has been elected president now who is upending and destroying a great many of our American values...he's trying to distort the American dream, which he's doing every hour of the day."{{cite web|url=http://www.ledger-enquirer.com/news/local/article129782459.html|title=Actor Hal Holbrook says Trump is trying to 'distort the American dream'|publisher=[[Ledger-Enquirer]]|accessdate=July 4, 2017|date=January 31, 2017|author=Chuck Williams}} Holbrook opposes President Trump's [[Executive Order 13769|immigration ban]] while praising the protests against the ban. ==Legacy== The local community of [[McLemoresville, Tennessee|McLemoresville]], [[Tennessee]], hometown of his wife [[Dixie Carter]], constructed the Dixie Theatre for Performing Arts in nearby [[Huntingdon, Tennessee|Huntingdon]], Tennessee, which features the Hal Holbrook Auditorium. On June 8, 2017, actor [[J. G. Hertzler]] announced his candidacy as a [[U.S. House Representative]] for [[New York's 23rd congressional district]] in the [[United States elections, 2018|2018 elections]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ithacajournal.com/story/news/2017/06/12/klingon-run-mark-twain-against-rep-reed/389053001/|title='Klingon' to run as 'Mark Twain' against Rep. Reed|first=Matt |last=Steecker|date=June 12, 2017|work=Ithaca Journal|accessdate=June 13, 2017}} In his campaign, he plans to act "in the persona of [[Mark Twain]]", to present his ideas "through the brilliant humorist for all ages" as a tribute both to Twain and to Holbrook.{{cite web|url=http://www.14850.com/06104035-hertzler-ny23-reed/|title="Star Trek" actor will challenge Tom Reed for New York 23rd - 14850|date=June 10, 2017 |first=Mark H. |last=Anbinder|website=14850.com|location=Ithaca, New York|accessdate=June 13, 2017}} Upon his retirement from his Mark Twain persona, ''[[HuffPost|The HuffPost]]'' hailed Holbrook as "the man who has done more to keep Mark Twain on people's minds than anyone else".{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hal-holbrook-says-farewell-to-legendary-mark-twain_us_59b9694ae4b06b71800c361f|title=Hal Holbrook Says Farewell to Legendary Mark Twain Role|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=September 16, 2017|date=September 13, 2017|author=Cindy Lovell}} ==Filmography== {{main|Hal Holbrook filmography}} ==Awards and nominations== {| {{Infobox Website |name = HealthNewsReview.org |logo = |screenshot = |caption = |url = http://healthnewsreview.org/ |alexa = |commercial = no |type = [[:Category:Review websites|Review website]] |language = English |registration = optional |owner = Schwitzer Health News LLC |author = Gary Schwitzer |launch date = 2006-04-16 |current status = online |revenue = }}
'''HealthNewsReview.org''' is a web-based project that rates the completeness, accuracy, and balance of news stories that include claims about medical treatments, tests, products and procedures. The Founder and Publisher is Gary Schwitzer, a health care journalist for more than four decades who is now an Adjunct Associate Professor in the University of Minnesota School of Public Health. The project's 10-point grading scale includes whether a story gives information about its sources and their competing interests, quantifies the benefits of a treatment, and appraises the evidence supporting the story's claims.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wise|first1=Jeff|title=HealthNewsReview.org’s Gary Schwitzer on What’s Wrong (and Right) With the Media|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/07/gary-schwitzer-problem-with-media.html|website=[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]|language=en|date=24 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Perry|first1=Susan|title=Confused by a drumbeat of health news 'dreck?' A Minnesota-based website aims to help|url=https://www.minnpost.com/second-opinion/2015/05/confused-drumbeat-health-news-dreck-minnesota-based-website-aims-help|website=[[MinnPost]]|language=en|date=1 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Mazer|first1=Benjamin|title=Journalists are not the end game: An interview with Gary Schwitzer|url=http://www.doctorsinoz.com/blog/interview-gary-schwitzer/|website=www.doctorsinoz.com|date=6 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brooks|first1=Jon|title=Does Health Journalism Do More Harm Than Good?|url=https://ww2.kqed.org/futureofyou/2016/05/16/is-health-journalism-doing-more-harm-than-good/|website=KQED Future of You|language=en-us|date=16 May 2016}}</ref>
In its first 22 months, the website reviewed 500 news stories, and found that they usually failed to discuss evidence quality, alternative options, costs, and absolute sizes of benefits and harms.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Schwitzer G |title= How do US journalists cover treatments, tests, products, and procedures? an evaluation of 500 stories |journal= PLoS Med |volume=5 |issue=5 |pages=e95 |year=2008 |pmid=18507496 |doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0050095 |url=http://www.plosmedicine.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pmed.0050095 |laysummary=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/jun/21/2 |laysource=Guardian |laydate=2008-06-21 |pmc= 2689661}}</ref> At that time, the editors of the journal PLoS Medicine wrote: “Schwitzer’s alarming report card of the trouble with medical news stories is thus a wake-up call for all of us involved in disseminating health research-researchers, academic institutions, journal editors, reporters, and media organizations-to work collaboratively to improve the standards of health reporting.” <ref>{{cite journal |author= The ''PLoS Medicine'' Editors |title= False hopes, unwarranted fears: the trouble with medical news stories |journal= PLoS Med |volume=5 |issue=5 |pages=e118 |year=2008 |pmid=18507502 |doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0050118 |url=http://www.plosmedicine.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pmed.0050118 |pmc= 2689669}}</ref> In 2011, [http://www.cjr.org/the_observatory/mixed_grades_for_med_coverage.php the Columbia Journalism Review website published an update] on the site's findings.
In 2006, the year the project launched, it was honored with a Knight-Batten Award for Innovations in Journalism.<ref>{{cite web|title=Knight-Batten Awards for Innovations in Journalism {{!}} J-Lab: The Institute for Interactive Journalism|url=http://www.j-lab.org/projects/knight-batten-awards-for-innovations-in-journalism/2006|website=www.j-lab.org}}</ref> In 2007, it won a Mirror Award to honor those "who hold a mirror to their own industry for the public’s benefit."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mirrorawards.syr.edu/press.html}}</ref> In 2009, Schwitzer's blog was named "Best Medical Blog" in competition hosted by Medgadget.com.<ref>{{cite web|title=2009 Medical Weblog Awards Sponsored by Epocrates: Meet the Winners! {{!}}|url=http://medgadget.com/2010/02/2009_medical_weblog_awards_sponsored_by_epocrates_meet_the_winners.html|website=Medgadget|date=19 February 2010}}</ref>
The organization once reviewed news on television but ceased in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Koerth-Baker|first1=Maggie|authorlink1=Maggie Koerth-Baker|title=Why HealthNewsReview.org Gave Up On TV|url=http://boingboing.net/2009/10/15/why-healthnewsreview.html|website=[[Boing Boing]]|date=15 October 2009}}</ref>
In 2014, Schwitzer published an article in the journal JAMA Internal Medicine, providing an update on the lessons learned after 8 years with the HealthNewsReview.org project.<ref>{{cite journal|author= Gary Schwitzer|title= A Guide To Reading Health Care News|journal= JAMA Intern Med |volume=174 |issue=7 |pages=1183–1186 |year=2014 |pmid=24796314 |doi=10.1001/jamainternmed.2014.1359 |url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/1867181}}</ref>
In 2015, the project also began systematically reviewing health care news releases written by public relations professionals. By 2018, the editorial team had reviewed more than 500 such PR news releases to go along with more than 2,500 reviews of news stories.
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://healthnewsreview.org/}} * [http://www.thehealthcaretoday.com official health news website]
