{{Expand list|date=February 2011}} {{cleanup |reason=The tables need better formatting and should be merged/combined with [[Timeline of time capsules]]. Also, many of the time capsules need sources.|date=June 2017}}
This is a '''list of [[time capsule]]s'''. The [[International Time Capsule Society]] estimates there are between 10,000 and 15,000 time capsules worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.oglethorpe.edu/about_us/crypt_of_civilization/international_time_capsule_society.asp|title= Oglethorpe University - International Time Capsule Society|accessdate= 2008-07-01|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080620232510/http://www.oglethorpe.edu/about_us/crypt_of_civilization/international_time_capsule_society.asp|archivedate= 2008-06-20|df= }}</ref>
== By country ==
=== Australia ===
==== Historical ====
On 29 September 1896, when the [[Perth Observatory]] foundation was laid, the occasion was attended by Sir [[John Forrest]] and other notable dignitaries. Several items of importance were placed in a 'leaden box', sealed and deposited in a cavity beneath the [[Cornerstone|foundation stone]]. The local press reported the event and mentioned here since "[[Röntgen rays]] tubes, and a description of the process, together with specimen photographs", donated by [[X-ray]] pioneer [[William John Hancock]] were included in the cache.<ref name="Editor. 1896 Page 2">Editor. (30 September 1896). The Perth Observatory. Laying the Foundation Stone. The West Australian. Perth. Western Australia. Page 2.</ref> This is the first known instance of a [[time capsule]] in [[Western Australia]], and in Australia.
Also in Western Australia, in celebration of the laying of the foundation stone of the Northam Railway Institute on 28 July 1897, laid by Mrs. Ann Throssell, the wife of the Commissioner of Crown Lands and local MP George Throssell, a bottle containing two copies of the ''Northam Advertiser'' newspaper and several coins was laid in a cavity beneath the foundation stone.<ref>The Northam Advertiser Saturday 31 July 1897 p 3</ref>
==== Contemporary ====
In celebration of its golden jubilee, Epping Boys High School of Sydney buried a time capsule in the foyer of its library, in 2007, to be unearthed in the centenary year. A previous time capsule was buried in 1982 to celebrate the silver jubilee. The town of Cowra in central Western New South Wales contained a time capsule which was buried near a sculpture of an eagle in the park not far from the town's information center. The capsule was opened in the year 2000 on an unspecified date, although the sculpture remains, there is no mention of the time capsule once buried there.
A time capsule is also located at Nailsworth Primary School in South Australia, being planted in 2001 to be opened in 2025, this capsule was planted to replace the 1977 capsule opened the same year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/AUS-SAGEN/2001-10/1004350483|title=RootsWeb: AUS-SAGEN-L [AUS-SAGEN] Reunions:Adelaide Advertiser- Sept/Oct 2001|author=|date=|website=archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com}}</ref> A time capsule is also present on the grounds of Melbourne High school in Victoria.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
A time capsule on [[Canberra]]'s City Hill was unveiled on 11 March 2013 to commemorate the city's centenary. It is to be unsealed in 2113.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2014/03/11/3961082.htm|title=Time capsule sealed inside Canberra's new Centenary Column|author=|date=11 March 2014|website=www.abc.net.au}}</ref>
On February 22, 2018, the Sunshine Coast Council concluded its celebration of the 50th Anniversary of the Naming of the Sunshine Coast by burying a historic time capsule.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.sunshinecoast.qld.gov.au/Council/News-Centre/SC50-time-capsule-unveiled-today-for-future|title=SC50 time capsule unveiled today for future|last=|first=|date=|work=Sunshine Coast Council|access-date=2018-03-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> The capsule contains a number of reports, documents, and objects from the year previous, and a letter from Mayor Mark Jamieson and 2017 Young Citizen of the Year, Jak Hardy, who was appointed its guardian through to 2067.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/sc50-time-capsule-unveiled-today-for-future/3343500/|title=SC50 time capsule unveiled today for future|work=Sunshine Coast Daily|access-date=2018-03-16|language=en}}</ref>
===Austria=== *[[Memory of Mankind]] in [[Hallstatt]].
=== Bermuda === In celebration of its 150th corporate anniversary, [[Bacardi]] Limited installed a 1.82m x 0.30m stainless steel time capsule, encased in a granite cap and cement pedestal, in front of the Bacardi worldwide headquarters in Bermuda. The capsule was placed in December 2012 and is intended to be opened in 2062, at the company's 200th anniversary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.multivu.com/mnr/53414-bacardi-rum-150-anniversary-time-capsule-artifacts-birthday-celebration |title=Bacardi Celebrates Culmination Of Its Milestone 150th Anniversary With Time Capsule To Be Opened In 50 Years |date=2012-12-13 |format= |accessdate=2013-03-29 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130329174256/http://www.multivu.com/mnr/53414-bacardi-rum-150-anniversary-time-capsule-artifacts-birthday-celebration |archivedate=2013-03-29 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
=== Canada === * A geologist left a bottled message in 1959 in a [[cairn]] on [[Ward Hunt Island]] (83°N latitude), allowing its finders in 2013 to determine that a nearby glacier had retreated over 200 feet in 54 years.<ref name="LATimes20131220">{{cite news |last1=Mohan |first1=Geoffrey |title=Message in a bottle found 54 years later in Arctic |url=http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-message-in-bottle-arctic-20131219-story.html |work=Los Angeles Times |date=December 20, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140706145108/http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-message-in-bottle-arctic-20131219-story.html |archivedate=July 6, 2014 |deadurl=no }}</ref> * Inside the head of the [[World's Largest Axe]] in [[Nackawic]], [[New Brunswick]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nackawic.com/pdf/International_Garden_and_worlds_largest_axe.doc |title=World's Largest Axe |last=Melanson |first=Craig |date=2006-05-12 |website=Town of Nackawic |access-date=2017-09-05 |format=DOC |page=2}}</ref> * 6 Feet underground in the [[Chinook Centre]] in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]]; to be opened on December 31st, 2999.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chinookcentre.com/en/centreinfo/Pages/FeaturesTimeCapsule.aspx |title=Time Capsule |website=Chinook Centre |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321054716/http://www.chinookcentre.com/en/centreinfo/Pages/FeaturesTimeCapsule.aspx |archive-date=2015-03-21 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * 1234 Main Street, [[Moncton]], [[New Brunswick]]{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * Inside [[Joseph Salter]] memorial, Main Street, [[Moncton]], [[New Brunswick]]{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * Inside the [[CN Tower]], in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]]. To be opened at the 100-year anniversary in 2076.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cntower.ca/en-ca/about-us/history/time-capsule.html|title=Time Capsule - CN Tower|website=CN Tower|publisher=CN Tower|accessdate=28 March 2018}}</ref>
=== Iceland === *Erected in 2014, the monument is located in Reykjavik, Iceland, has of three differently shaped 15 feet tall spires, two made of stone and one metal center pillar. <ref>http://www.slate.com/blogs/atlas_obscura/2016/08/29/reykjavik_iceland_s_eve_online_monument_is_an_irl_tribute_to_its_dedicated.html</ref>
===India=== * Indian Prime Minister [[Indira Gandhi]] had buried a time capsule outside one of the gate of [[Red Fort]] complex,The Indira Gandhi government named this time capsule "Kalpaatra", Delhi containing post-independence history of India on 15 August 1972 amid political opposition. It was scheduled to be opened after 1000 years. The next [[Janata Party|Janata government]] unearthed it in 1977 but its contents were never made public and were lost.<ref name="Jarvis2002">{{cite book|author=William E. Jarvis|title=Time Capsules: A Cultural History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GKuzCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA170|date=11 November 2002|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-1261-7|page=170}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post 1977">{{cite web | title=India's Fleeting Time Capsule | website=Washington Post | date=1977-12-02 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1977/12/02/indias-fleeting-time-capsule/47004ab6-cad9-4db7-92ae-9e95cc0cce8b/ | accessdate=2016-11-19}}</ref><ref name="India Today 31121977 2014">{{cite web | title=Images India | website=India Today 31121977 | date=2014-05-16 | url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/mahatma-gandhi-my-experiments-with-truth-indira-gandhi-emergency-indian-army/1/435817.html | accessdate=2016-11-19}}</ref><ref name="News18 2016">{{cite web | title=A Fort, a Time Capsule, a Secret: The Many Mysteries of Indira Gandhi | website=News18 | date=2016-08-11 | url=http://www.news18.com/news/india/a-fort-a-time-capsule-a-secret-the-many-mysteries-of-indira-gandhi-1280368.html | accessdate=2016-11-19}}</ref> * A time capsule was buried in the presence of the [[President of India]] near the auditorium of [[IIT Kanpur]] on 6 March 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=President of India buries the Time Capsule |url=http://www.cse.iitk.ac.in/users/gj/new/Events/Presidentvisit.pdf |publisher=IIT Kanpur |date=6 March 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119142559/http://www.cse.iitk.ac.in/users/gj/new/Events/Presidentvisit.pdf |archivedate=19 November 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Springer Nature 2010">{{cite journal | title=Tech school buries history for posterity | journal=Nature India | publisher=Springer Nature | year=2010 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nindia.2010.84 | doi=10.1038/nindia.2010.84 | accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> * [[Mahatma Mandir]], [[Gandhinagar]] containing the history of Indian state of [[Gujarat]] marking the 50 years of its foundation. Installed in 2010.<ref name="tcie">{{cite news | url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/state-s-time-capsule-to-be-installed-at-mahatma-mandir-today/630351 | title=State’s time capsule to be installed at Mahatma Mandir today | work=[[The Indian Express]] | date=June 7, 2010 | agency=[[Press Trust of India]] | accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref><ref name="The Telegraph 1973">{{cite web | title=Blemish buried in buried history | website=The Telegraph | date=15 August 1973 | url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1110617/jsp/frontpage/story_14124988.jsp | accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> * Alexandra Girls' English Institution, a school in [[Fort (Mumbai precinct)|Fort, South Mumbai]] buried a time capsule in 2014, scheduling it to be opened on 1 September 2062, on the bi-centennial anniversary of the school.<ref name="Borwankar 2014">{{cite web | last=Borwankar | first=Vinamrata | title=Back to the past: South Mumbai school to bury a time capsule | website=dna | date=25 March 2014 | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-back-to-the-past-south-mumbai-school-to-bury-a-time-capsule-1971935 | accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref>
=== Israel === * A time capsule was installed under [[Eretz Israel Museum]] in [[Tel Aviv]] at 30 December 1999. It is scheduled to be opened 100 years later.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
=== Kazakhstan === * In [[Aktau]], people of 1967 sent a message showing the chronology of the development of [[Mangyshlak Peninsula]] with the names of the people who helped to build the town in the desert. The letter was put in a metallic cylinder in a triangular marble urn. It opened in November 2017.<ref>[http://ogni.kz/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5063&Itemid=2 Aktau: Years, people, memories...] Ogni.kz on 13 October 2011</ref>
===Malaysia=== * Rotary Club Time Capsule Monument (GPS: 3.15912, 101.69825) is a commemorative monument along Jalan Sultan Ismail in [[Kuala Lumpur]]. It was originally located at [[Dataran Merdeka]], but was relocated to Jalan Sultan Ismail around 2016. It comprises a stainless steel column topped with a [[Rotary International]] logo. At the base is a black marble-encased pedestal under which a time capsule is buried. The monument was erected to celebrate the presence of Rotary in [[Malaysia]] since 1929. It was officiated by the mayor of Kuala Lumpur, Tan Sri Dato' Kamaruzzaman bin Shariff, on 26 June, 2000.
===Norway=== * On September 17, 2017 near the [[Polish Polar Station, Hornsund]] in the Norwegian [[Svalbard]] archipelago, scientific researchers buried a 60-centimeter stainless steel tube containing samples designed to tell finders as long as half a million years into the future, about the current state of knowledge in such areas as geology, biology, and technology.<ref name=20170929Nature>{{cite web |last1=Schiermeier |first1=Quirin |title=Time capsule buried to preserve science for the ages -- Message in a bottle sums up state of research in 2017 |url=https://www.nature.com/news/time-capsule-buried-to-preserve-science-for-the-ages-1.22657 |publisher=''Nature'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171002161539/https://www.nature.com/news/time-capsule-buried-to-preserve-science-for-the-ages-1.22657 |archivedate=October 2, 2017 |date=September 29, 2017 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
=== Poland === * Prisoners from the [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] concealed bottles containing sketches<ref name=Spiegel20120117>{{cite web |last1=Macbeth |first1=Alex |title='Witness to Extermination': Auschwitz Museum Publishes Prisoner Sketchbook |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/witness-to-extermination-auschwitz-museum-publishes-prisoner-sketchbook-a-809591.html |publisher=''Der Spiegel'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418031130/http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/witness-to-extermination-auschwitz-museum-publishes-prisoner-sketchbook-a-809591.html |archivedate=April 18, 2016 |date=January 17, 2012 |deadurl=no}} Detailed sketches were found in a camp barracks in 1947.</ref> and writings<ref name=BBCNews20090427Novýčas20090430> • {{cite web |title=Builders find Auschwitz message |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8021845.stm |publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' |date=April 27, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170307130950/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8021845.stm |archivedate=March 7, 2017 |deadurl=no}} Short prisoner list was found in 2009 in a wall of a bomb shelter that prisoners were forced to build. • {{cite web|title=Záhadný odkaz väzňov v Osvienčime: Autor je už známy! (Mysterious link from prisoners in Auschwitz: The author is already known!) |url=http://www.cas.sk/clanok/115020/zahadny-odkaz-vaznov-v-osviencime-autor-je-uz-znamy/ |publisher=''Nový čas'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160729151358/http://www.cas.sk/clanok/115020/zahadny-odkaz-vaznov-v-osviencime-autor-je-uz-znamy/ |archivedate=July 29, 2016 |language=Slovak |date=April 30, 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> that were found after World War II. *In 2016, a copper-cylinder time capsule dating to 1934 was found beneath the former Nazi training facility in the [[Ordensburg Krössinsee]] building in [[Złocieniec]], Poland.<ref name=Indep20160916/> The time capsule, which contained photographs, newspapers, coins, and two copies of Hitler's ''[[Mein Kampf]],'' was retrieved by researchers who navigated through thick concrete, German mines, and groundwater.<ref name=Indep20160916>{{cite web |last1=Eleftheriou-Smith |first1=Loulla-Mae |title=Nazi time capsule: Newspapers, photographs and copies of Mein Kampf found ‘perfectly preserved’ in Poland |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/nazi-time-capsule-poland-mein-kampf-adolf-hitler-discovery-photos-a7315771.html |publisher=''The Independent'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011212314/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/nazi-time-capsule-poland-mein-kampf-adolf-hitler-discovery-photos-a7315771.html |archivedate=October 11, 2016 |date=September 16, 2016 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
=== Russia === * In 2012 a time capsule dating from July 15, 1979 was found in Vulkanny ([[Yelizovsky District]], [[Kamchatka peninsula]]) under a statue of Lenin. It contained messages to the "socialist society in 2024."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://facepunch.com/showthread.php?t=1200453 |title=Time capsule found under the statue of Lenin in Moscow |date=2012-07-25 |format= |accessdate=2013-03-26 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FOyYmsdL?url=http://facepunch.com/showthread.php?t=1200453 |archivedate=2013-03-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
=== Singapore === * The oldest known time capsule in Singapore was rediscovered in early 2016, beneath the foundation stone of the [[Cathedral of the Good Shepherd]]. The shoebox-sized time capsule from June 18, 1843 was found to include a prayer booklet and newspapers, and international coins.<ref name=Statesman20160703/> The capsule is thought to have been buried by French Catholic missionary priests and other founding communities of Singapore.<ref name=Statesman20160703>{{cite web |last1=Zaccheus |first1=Melody |title=Message in a bottle |url=http://www.thestatesman.com/news/evolve/message-in-a-bottle/151843.html |publisher=''The Statesman'' (India) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160720212207/http://www.thestatesman.com/news/evolve/message-in-a-bottle/151843.html |archivedate=July 20, 2016 |date=July 3, 2016 |deadurl=no}}</ref>. * On 1 April 1937 a capsule containing coins and newspapers from the time was buried under the foundation stone of the [[Old Supreme Court Building, Singapore|former Supreme Court building]] with the intention that it be opened in the year 3000. The building now houses the [[National Gallery Singapore]], where the foundation stone can still be seen today. * In 1949 a capsule was buried at [[Anglo-Chinese School (Barker Road)]] containing school magazines, a bible and records of major donors. Thought to be lost, the capsule was rediscovered in 2000 with the help of a former student who had attended the burial ceremony. * A capsule buried in 1950 under the then Royal Island Club (now the Singapore Island Country Club) was thought to be lost but later found by construction workers in 2010. It contained photographs and newspapers. * In 1970, one of Singapore's founding leaders, [[Goh Keng Swee|Dr Goh Keng Swee]] laid a [[copper]] cylinder containing newspapers and Singapore bank notes from the era, somewhere in the [[Former National Stadium, Singapore|former National Stadium]]. Unfortunately the location has been lost and metal detectors have failed to find it despite a $50,000 reward on offer <ref name=SGTimeCapsules>{{cite web |title=6 interesting facts about SG50 and other time capsules unearthed |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/sg50-time-capsule-sealed-6-interesting-facts-about-time-capsules-unearthed |publisher=''Straits Times''}}</ref>. * Since 1973, [[Science Centre Singapore]] has been depositing gadgets and examples of significant technologies in a time capsule inaugurated by then Science and Technology Minister [[Toh Chin Chye|Dr Toh Chin Chye]]. The first 112 items deposited included a black and white television receiver, a camera and samples of pig feed. After additional deposits were made in 1983, 2001 and 2013 the original capsule was replaced with a larger [[stainless steel]] container that now holds over 800 items in an atmosphere of inert [[nitrogen]] gas in the hope that this will better preserve the artefacts inside<ref name=SGTimeCapsules/>. * The [[Jurong Town Corporation]] buried a time capsule under [[Jurong Town Hall]] in 1974. When opened in 2001, the capsule was found to contain reports, articles and photographs illustrating the industrialisation of [[Jurong]]. * In 1975, part of Singapore's contribution to an International Ocean Exposition held in [[Okinawa]], [[Japan]] entitled ''The Sea We Would Like to See'' was a research project using floating time capsules. The previous year, 50 small round capsules were released from [[Raffles Lighthouse]] as part of a global fleet of 2,800 to measure oceanic tides and currents. Each capsule contained information about the Exposition, a goodwill message from a Japanese child and a voucher for a [[Citizen Watch|Citizen]] ''Blackie'' watch to incentivise finders to fill in a post card with details of where the capsule were found. 24 of the capsules released in Singapore were later recovered. * 1990 saw the unexpected unearthing of a time capsule from the 1950s by contractors working at the demolished American Insurance building in Robinson Road. Buried on April 26, 1956, the copper canister contained English and Chinese newspapers, a financial report, photographs, posters and an insurance agent's manual<ref name=SGTimeCapsules/>. * In 2015, a time capsule buried to celebrate Singapore's 25th year of independence was dug up and replaced with one celebrating 50 years as a sovereign nation. The original canister held 88 "symbols of progress" including a [[video tape]] of the 1966 [[National Day Parade|National Day (Singapore)]], water from the [[Singapore River]] and the first [[Kebaya|sarong kebaya]] uniforms designed by [[Pierre Balmain]] for [[Singapore Airlines]] in 1968. The replacement capsule, made from [[stainless steel]], was buried by then Deputy Prime Minister [[Ong Teng Cheong]] outside Empress Place<ref name=SGTimeCapsules/>. * On 31 August 2005, [[Singapore Polytechnic]] buried a time capsule in order to conclude year-long celebrations of its [[50th anniversary]] of its founding in 1954.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sp.edu.sg/wps/portal/vp-spws/spws.org.abtsp.story.sptimeline|title=SP Timeline - Singapore Polytechnic|last=|first=|date=29 August 2017|website=Singapore Polytechnic|access-date=}}</ref> Located near its main library, it is scheduled to be re-opened in 2029 for its 75th anniversary.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://myspmemories.sp.edu.sg/TimeLine/50th-Anniversary-Time-Capsule?Id=15#1|title=The Time Capsule Ceremony|last=|first=|date=29 August 2017|website=My SP Memories|access-date=}}</ref> Items in the time capsule included staff and student admission cards, a CD of 2004's graduation ceremony and a bottle of locally brewed red wine.
=== Spain === * An 1834 time capsule was discovered in 2009 under a statue of [[Miguel de Cervantes]] in Madrid. It contains a guide and four volumes of the 1819 edition of ''[[Don Quixote]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.es.msn.com/watch/video/abierta-la-capsula-del-tiempo/6vm3hvzq?from=truveo |title=Abierta la cápsula del tiempo en MSN Vídeo |publisher=Video.es.msn.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-15}}</ref> * A time capsule was buried in [[Motril]], [[Granada]]. It will be opened on July 22, 2023 to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the cantonal movement.<ref>{{cite web|author=Publicado por MD |url=http://motrildigital.blogspot.com/2008/07/motril-albergar-la-segunda-cpsula-del.html |title=motril digital: Motril albergará la segunda cápsula del tiempo existente en España |publisher=Motrildigital.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-15}}</ref>
* A 1777 time capsule was discovered within a religious statue in Sotillo de la Ribera (Burgos). It contained two handwritten pages describing details of the political, religious, and economic situation of the region at the time.<ref>{{cite web|author=Diario ABC |url=http://www.abc.es/espana/castilla-leon/abci-hallan-capsula-tiempo-oculta-talla-siglo-xviii-201711272030_noticia.html?#ns_campaign=mod-outbrain&ns_mchannel=abc.es&ns_source=organico&ns_linkname=mobile&ns_fee=MB_21|title=Hallan una cápsula del tiempo oculta en una talla del siglo XVIII |date= |accessdate=2017-11-27}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === * [[Kingussie]], Scotland: in August 2015 workers discovered a metal box containing a newspaper from 29 September 1894, a paper scroll and a bottle believed to contain whisky.|<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-34054847|title=121-year-old time capsule found at bridge near Kingussie|date=26 August 2015|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Macclesfield]], Cheshire: in April 2010 an urn container from 1876 was found under a granite slab in the United Reformed Church. The content (newspapers and photographs) was perfectly preserved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1269668/Time-capsule-dating-1876-discovered-buried-underneath-church-memorial.html |title=Time capsule dating back to 1876 discovered buried underneath church memorial |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2013-03-26 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FP1FDt83?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1269668/Time-capsule-dating-1876-discovered-buried-underneath-church-memorial.html |archivedate=2013-03-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Newton Aycliffe]], [[County Durham]], England: On 21 March 2017 a time capsule bearing the name of its creator, James D Robinson, was 'sealed' at an informal gathering in a local church hall. It was subsequently transferred to the nearby Durham County Record Office, at County Hall, in the City of Durham, where it will reside in their archive facility for the next 300 years. The capsule contains an eclectic mix of texts and images along with a number of artefacts, and is scheduled to be opened on 21 March 2317. * The children's television show [[Blue Peter]] have buried several time capsules during the programme's run. Ones buried in London in 1971 and 1984 were opened in January 2000. A third was then buried to be opened in 2029, which has since been relocated to [[Salford, Greater Manchester]]. One was also placed under the [[Millennium Dome]] in London in 1998, to be opened in 2050,<ref>{{cite book|title=The Book Of Lists, London|author=Rennison, Nick|publisher=Canongate|year=2006|page=277}}</ref> but was accidentally unearthed and damaged during construction work in 2017. It will be reburied once it has been repaired.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38838033|title=Blue Peter time capsule dug up 33 years early|date=2017-02-02|accessdate=2017-02-02}}</ref> * [[Southampton]], Hampshire: a 1935 message in a lemonade bottle, correctly portending difficult times lying ahead, was found in 2016 by masons restoring damaged Portland stone at [[Southampton Guildhall]].<ref name=ITV20160209>{{cite web |title='Message in a bottle' discovered in Southampton |url=http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/2016-02-09/message-in-a-bottle-discovered-in-southampton/ |publisher=ITV |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160210164227/http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/2016-02-09/message-in-a-bottle-discovered-in-southampton/ |archivedate=February 10, 2016 |date=February 9, 2016 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
=== United States ===
* Richmond, Indiana. Time capsule placed in cornerstone of YMCA in 1955.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * On June 15, 1957, as part of the celebration of the 50th anniversary of [[Oklahoma]] statehood, a 1957 [[Plymouth Belvedere]] car was sealed in an underground vault in [[Tulsa]], to be unearthed 50 years later on June 14, 2007 during Oklahoma's centennial celebration. Several items were left in the car's trunk and glove compartment, such as a 5 US gallon can of gasoline intended to start the car, should gasoline not be the fuel of choice for motor vehicles in 2007. A contest also took place, in which the contestant who came the closest to guessing the city population in 2007, would then be awarded the car and $100 in a savings account. * Time Capsule in ghost town, [[Centralia, Pennsylvania|Centralia]], [[Pennsylvania (U.S. state)|Pennsylvania]] was to be opened in 2016 but was opened in 2014 instead. Within the time capsule was about two feet of water destroying most paper artifacts in the capsule. A miner's helmet and a pair of bloomers signed by the men living in the city at the time are among artifacts that remained.<ref>{{cite web|title=Centralia PA Time Capsule opened early|url=http://www.centraliapa.org/centralia-pennsylvania-time-capsule-opened-early-2014/|website=www.centraliapa.org|accessdate=2016-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/fire-in-the-hole-77895126/|title=Fire in the Hole|last1=Krajick|first1=Krajick|publisher=Smithsonian Magazine|issue=May 2005|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref> * [[Crypt of Civilization]] in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]<ref name="oglethorpe.edu">http://www.oglethorpe.edu/about_us/crypt_of_civilization/|Oglethorpe University official web site, retrieved 5 May 2013</ref> * [[Westinghouse Time Capsules]] in [[New York City]]<ref name="Manufacturing Company 1939">Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, The Story of Westinghouse Time Capsule of cupaloy (1939)</ref> * [[Don Harrington Discovery Center|Helium Centennial Time Columns Monument]] in [[Amarillo, Texas]]<ref name=Helium1968/> * Disneyland 40th Anniversary Time Capsule in [[Anaheim]], [[California (U.S. state)|California]]; to open in July 2035{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * [[Green-Wood Cemetery]], Brooklyn, NY: a time capsule placed in a cornerstone in 1954 was found in January 2013<ref name="Time Capsule Discovered">{{cite web|url=http://www.green-wood.com/2013/time-capsule-discovered/ |title=Time Capsule Discovered |date=2013-01-22 |format= |accessdate=2013-03-26 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FP0pwzma?url=http://www.green-wood.com/2013/time-capsule-discovered/ |archivedate=2013-03-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Salt Lake City]], 78 S. It was moved to the [[Nickelodeon Suites Resort Orlando]] in 2005 and later to the [[Nickelodeon Animation Studio]] in 2016, and will be opened in 2042.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/31016/every-item-inside-time-capsule-nickelodeon-buried-1992|title=Every Item in Nickelodeon's 1992 Time Capsule|author=|date=25 June 2012|website=mentalfloss.com}}</ref> * Time capsule in [[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho]].{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * Time capsule encased in cement at the entrance of the Miami Dade County Courthouse, 73 W. Flagler, St., Miami, Florida. To be opened on Sept. 17, 2087.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * The [[Samuel Adams and Paul Revere Time Capsule]] was found under the Golden Dome of the Massachusetts State House in December 2014. It is believed to have been buried in 1795 by then-Governor Samuel Adams and Paul Revere, and contained newspapers, a commonwealth seal, colony records, coins, a silver plate, and copper medal. It was uncovered, then added to and replaced, in 1855. Being 219 years old, it is the oldest time capsule to be discovered in the United States.<ref name=CNN20150107>{{cite web|last1=Shoichet |first1=Catherine E. |title=1795 time capsule opened, centuries after Revere and Adams buried it |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/01/06/us/feat-paul-revere-sam-adams-boston-time-capsule/index.html |publisher=CNN |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310223909/http://www.cnn.com/2015/01/06/us/feat-paul-revere-sam-adams-boston-time-capsule/index.html |archivedate=March 10, 2016 |date=January 7, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/boston-unearthing-paul-revere-time-capsule-from-1795-2014-12|title=Boston Is Digging Up What Could Be The Oldest Unopened Time Capsule Ever|author=|date=|website=businessinsider.com}}</ref> * On September 1, 1975, a time capsule was buried at the intersection of 7th and Main in [[Louisville, Kentucky]] to be opened in 100 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unusualkentucky.blogspot.com/2010/03/louisville-bicentennial-time-capsule.html|title=Unusual Kentucky: Louisville Bicentennial Time Capsule|first=|last=Jsh|date=12 March 2010|website=unusualkentucky.blogspot.com}}</ref> * A time capsule was buried in 1984 by patrons of the nightclub [[Danceteria]]. Intended to be opened in the year 6984, it was instead uncovered by construction workers in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/radio/asithappens/as-it-happens-thursday-edition-1.4192830/the-sparkling-and-wonderful-story-behind-the-time-capsule-that-caused-a-nyc-bomb-scare-1.4192834|title=The 'sparkling and wonderful' story behind the time capsule that caused a NYC bomb scare|publisher=[[As It Happens]]|date= July 6, 2017|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref> * [[File:216932main time cap 226(1).gif|thumb|Time capsule at NASA Glenn Research Center]]On January 23, 1991 a time capsule was placed in a sculpture at NASA Lewis (now Glenn) Research Center, celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Center's groundbreaking. The capsule is scheduled to be opened on January 23, 2041.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glenn's 50th Anniversary Time Capsule|url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers/glenn/about/history/timecpsl.html|website=National Aeronautics and Space Administration|publisher=NASA|accessdate=26 July 2017}}</ref> * On January 14, 2000, Livermore California buried two time capsules. Information at http://www.lhg.org/time. One capsule may have been reburied from a previous burial. * Time capsule at St. Joseph School in [[Mendham, NJ]].{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * The largest time capsule in the world is located in Seward, Nebraska, containing over 5,000 items, one of which is a Chevy Vega. It opens in July 2025.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/15985|title=World's Largest Time Capsule, Seward, Nebraska|website=RoadsideAmerica.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ketv.com/article/seward-time-capsule-nears-2025-opening/22148018|title=Seward time capsule nears 2025 opening|last=Ozaki|first=Andrew|date=2018-07-16|work=KETV|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en}}</ref> * On August 1, 1969 Wayne Centennial Time Capsule was placed in Wayne, MI and is due to be opened on August 1, 2069. [http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WM2J56_Wayne_Centennial_Time_Capsule_Wayne_Michigan] * On September 3, 2013 [[Perry Hall High School]] buried a time capsule on the occasion of the school's 50th anniversary. It is to be opened on September 3, 2063.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://patch.com/maryland/perryhall/perry-hall-time-capsuleare-you-inside|title=Perry Hall Time Capsule—Are You Inside?, Perry Hall, Maryland|language=en|date= August 28, 2013|access-date=2018-07-08}}</ref> * In August 2018 [[http://www.seapinesmontessori.com Sea Pines Montessori Academy]] buried a time capsule on the occasion of the school's 50th anniversary. It is to be buried in [http://www.hiltonhead-sc.com/harbour-town.html Harbour Town] on Hilton Head Island, South Carolina and opened in August 2068. *[[Boulder, Colorado]]: The courthouse plaza at [[Pearl Street Mall]] has two time capsules: one to be opened in 2075, the other in 2096.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.openstreetmap.org/search?query=time%20capsule%2C%2080306|title=OpenStreetMap search|last=|first=|date=|website=OpenStreetMap|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-30}}</ref>

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} [[File:Manspreading on Stockholm Metro.jpg|thumb|An example of "manspreading" on the [[Stockholm metro]]]] '''Manspreading''' or '''man-sitting''' or '''ballrooming''' is the practice of men sitting in public transport with legs wide apart, thereby covering more than one seat.<ref name="nytsimmons">{{Cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/21/nyregion/MTA-targets-manspreading-on-new-york-city-subways.html |title = A Scourge Is Spreading. M.T.A.’s Cure? Dude, Close Your Legs. |last = Fitzsimmons |first = Emma G. |date = 20 December 2014 |work =The New York Times | access-date = }}</ref><ref name=":0" /> Both this posture and the use of the [[neologism]] "manspreading" have occasioned some internet criticism and debates in the US, UK, Turkey, and Canada.<ref>Radhika Sanghani, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/womens-life/11309866/Ban-manspreading-Brits-want-men-to-sit-with-their-legs-together.html "'Ban manspreading': Londoners want men to sit with their legs together on the Tube"], ''The Telegraph'', 23 December 2014.</ref><ref name=Seattle>{{Cite news |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/17/us-usa-transportation-manspreading-idUSKBN0KQ01120150117 |title = One body, one seat: Seattle's campaign against the 'manspreading' scourge |last = Johnson |first = Eric M. |date = 16 January 2015 | work = | access-date = | publisher = Reuters}}</ref> The public debate began when an anti-manspreading campaign started on the [[social media]] website [[Tumblr]] in 2013; the term appeared a year later.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://blog.oxforddictionaries.com/2015/09/manspreading-term-popularized-by-mta/|title= Manspreading: how New York City’s MTA popularized a word without actually saying it|author= Katherine Connor Martin|publisher= Oxford Dictionaries|year= 2015|accessdate= 2016-07-12}}</ref> [[OxfordDictionaries.com]] added the word "manspreading" in August 2015.<ref name="reuters">{{Cite news |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/27/us-life-manspread-idUSKCN0QW1Y620150827 |title = Manspreading, hangry, Grexit join Oxford online dictionary |date = 27 August 2015 |work = | access-date = | publisher = Reuters}} </ref><ref> {{cite web |title= New words in oxforddictionaries |url= https://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/aug/27/hangry-bants-fatberg-new-words-in-oxforddictionaries |accessdate= 28 August 2015 }} </ref> Use of the term has been criticized as "a caricature of feminism" and the practice has been juxtaposed with examples of women taking up excessive space in public spaces with bags.<ref name=":0"/><ref name = "Crane"/>
==Transit authority responses== [[File:EMT Madrid amplía su señalización a bordo del autobús para evitar el “manspreading” (01).jpg|thumb|Campaign encouraging respectful posture by [[Empresa Municipal de Transportes de Madrid|Madrid Municipal Transport Company]] in 2017.]] The [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] (MTA) in the [[New York metropolitan area]] and [[Sound Transit]] of [[Seattle]] instituted poster campaigns encouraging respectful posture when other passengers have to stand due to crowding on buses and trains. Transport officials in [[Philadelphia]], [[Chicago]] and [[Washington D.C.]] have not noted complaints against manspreading in particular.<ref name="nytsimmons" /> A representative of the [[Toronto Transit Commission]] stated they were unaware of complaints against manspreading, but did cite complaints against other etiquette problems, including taking up extra seats with handbags.<ref name = "TorontoSun">{{cite news|last1=Yuen|first1=Jenny|title=Anti-'manspreading' campaign called sexist|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2014/12/29/anti-manspreading-campaign-called-sexist|accessdate=5 December 2015|publisher=The Toronto Sun|date=5 December 2015}}</ref> The MTA campaign, which criticised many behaviors such as leaning on poles and applying make-up, used the slogan "Dude, stop the spread please!"<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Mumbais-got-its-own-man-spreaders/articleshow/45609512.cms|title = Mumbai’s got its own 'man-spreaders'|last = Tahseen|first = Ismat|date = 23 December 2014|work =The Times of India |access-date = |publisher = }}</ref> Since 2017 taking more than one seat is forbidden by [[Madrid Municipal Transport Company]].<ref>http://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/08/europe/madrid-manspreading-transit-trnd/index.html</ref> In some cases, people who find manspreading offensive have taken to photographing manspreading, and posting those images on the Internet.<ref name="nytsimmons" />
==Criticism== [[File:Shebagging_in_London.jpg|thumb|right|Woman on [[London Underground]], "she-bagging" by taking up the adjacent seat]] The criticism and campaigns against manspreading have been counter-criticized for not addressing similar behavior by women, such as taking up adjacent seats with bags, or "she-bagging." The controversy surrounding manspreading has been described by [[equity feminist]] [[Cathy Young]] as "pseudo feminism – preoccupied with male misbehavior, no matter how trivial."<ref name=":0">Cathy Young, [http://www.newsday.com/opinion/columnists/cathy-young/manspreading-but-women-hog-subway-space-too-cathy-young-1.9776186 "'Manspreading'? But women hog subway space, too"], ''Newsday'', 5 January 2015.</ref> Twitter-campaigns with the hashtag #manspreading have also been accompanied by hashtags like #shebagging.<ref name = "Crane">{{cite news|last1=Crane|first1=Emily|title=Are you a man-spreader or a she-bagger? As the U.S. makes selfish behaviour on public transport a criminal offence – Australian commuters think it might be time to follow suit|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3110093/Are-man-spreader-bagger-U-S-brings-laws-banning-practice-Australian-commuters-think-time-follow-them.html|accessdate=5 December 2015|publisher=Daily Mail |location= Australia|date=3 June 2015}}</ref> The practice of posting pictures of manspreading taken on subways, buses, and other modes of transportation online has been described as a form of [[online shaming|public shaming]].<ref name="Public Shaming">{{cite web|last1=Devon|first1=Natasha|title=The rise of stranger shaming: How humiliating others became acceptable|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/features/the-rise-of-stranger-shaming-how-humiliating-others-became-acceptable-9982260.html|work=The Independent |date=16 January 2015}}</ref> As an example, in New York, actor [[Tom Hanks]] was photographed on the subway, taking up two seats and criticized for it. He responded on a talk show, "Hey Internet, you idiot! The train was half empty! It was scattered – there was plenty of room!"<ref name=Hanks>{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Laurel|title=Tom Hanks defends his 'manspreading' subway style on James Corden's Late Late Show debut|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3009585/Tom-Hanks-defends-manspreading-subway-style-James-Corden-s-Late-Late-debut.html|accessdate=8 December 2015|publisher=The Daily Mail |location= UK|date=24 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Friedman|first1=Megan|title=Tom Hanks Defends His "Manspreading" Subway Habit|url=http://www.elle.com/culture/celebrities/news/a27445/tom-hanks-manspreading-subway/|website=Elle.com|publisher=Hearst Publishing|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
The [[Canadian Association for Equality]] (CAFE), a Canadian [[men's rights group]], has been critical of campaigns against manspreading by transit authorities. The CAFE has argued that it is "physically painful for men to close their legs" and that campaigns against manspreading is comparable to "[forcing] women to stop breast feeding on busses (sic) or trains...".<ref name=star>{{cite news|last1=Otis|first1=Daniel|title=Man-spreading, a transit controversy with legs|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2014/12/28/manspreading_a_transit_controversy_with_legs.html|accessdate=8 December 2015|publisher=The Toronto Star|date=28 December 2014}}</ref> Commentators in media have made similar arguments regarding the need for men to spread their legs to properly accommodate their [[testicles]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/11374213/Is-the-manspreading-campaign-just-prejudice-against-big-guys.html|title=Is the 'manspreading' campaign just prejudice against big guys?|first=Gareth|last=May|publisher=The Telegraph|date=30 January 2015|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref>
In 2016 the word appeared on [[Lake Superior State University]]'s list of "banished" words and phrases.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/01/us/banished-words-lake-superior-state-university.html|title='Manspreading', 'Vape' and 'So': Hated words for 2016|first=Christine|last=Hauser|publisher=The New York Times|date=31 December 2015|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref>
==Social signalling== Sitting more expansively may signal dominance and sexual attractiveness for males. Tanya Vacharkulksemsuk, a [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]] post-doctorate researcher recently published studies that found spreading out legs and arms is more sexually attractive when males do it. Using photographs, she found that images of men spreading out got 87% of interest among female viewers. Expansive poses were not as effective for women, who appeared "vulnerable" and "starfish-like" according to other researchers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Khazan|first1=Olga|title=Does Manspreading Work?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2016/03/is-manspreading-sexy/475728/|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=15 May 2016|date=29 March 2016}}</ref> On the other hand, some analysts have found that women sitting cross-legged may be perceived positively as an expression of femininity.<ref>Burns‐Ardolino, Wendy A. (2003). "Reading woman: Displacing the foundations of femininity." ''Hypatia'' 18.3 (2003): 42–59.</ref> The opposite seating posture to manspreading, leg-crossing, is often viewed as effeminate.<ref>Barlow, David H., E. Joyce Reynolds, and W. Stewart Agras. "Gender identity change in a transsexual." ''Archives of General Psychiatry'' 28.4 (1973): 569–76.</ref>

{{primary sources|date=December 2011}}{{notability|date=December 2011}} '''New Ways of Analyzing Variation Asia-Pacific (NWAV Asia-Pacific)''' is an annual [[academic conference]] in [[sociolinguistics]] and the first sister conference of [[New Ways of Analyzing Variation]]. NWAV Asia-Pacific focuses on research based on [[empirical data]] with an emphasis on [[Statistics|quantitative analysis]] of [[variation (linguistics)|variation and change]] across the [[Asia-Pacific]] region, including [[speech communities]], [[multilingualism]], [[urbanization]] and [[Human migration|migration]], sociophonetics, [[style-shifting]], [[language contact]], variation in minority languages, [[dialect]] variation and change, dialect contact, variation in [[Language acquisition|acquisition]], language change across the lifespan, [[perceptual dialectology]], and other related topics such as technological resources for sociolinguistic research. The first NWAV Asia-Pacific conference was held at [[University of Delhi]], India in February, 2011, which included an inaugural conference address by [[William Labov]]. NWAV Asia-Pacific 2 was held in [http://www.ninjal.ac.jp/socioling/nwavap02/ Tokyo] in August 2012 at the National Institute for Japanese Language and Linguistics. NWAV Asia-Pacific 3, hosted by [[Victoria University of Wellington]], took place 1-3 May 2014 in New Zealand. The fourth conference in the series, NWAV Asia-Pacific 4, was held at National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi, Taiwan, in April 2016, featuring invited presenters William Labov, Gillian Sankoff, James Myers, Dennis Preston, Miriam Meyerhoff, Daming Xu and Jingwei Zhang. NWAV-AP5 will be held in Brisbane, Australia in 2018.
The NWAV Asia/Pacific conference series has also led to the founding of a new peer-reviewed journal focused on language variation and change in this region: [https://benjamins.com/#catalog/journals/aplv/main Asia-Pacific Language Variation] (Benjamins Publishing).

'''Organic work''' ({{lang-pl|praca organiczna}}) was a term adopted from [[Herbert Spencer]] by the 19th century [[Poland|Polish]] [[positivism|positivists]], denoting an ideology demanding that the vital powers of the nation be spent on labour (i.e. work at the foundations) rather than fruitless national uprisings against the overwhelming military presence of [[Partitions of Poland|the neighbouring empires]]. The basic principles of the organic work included education of the masses and increase of the economical potential of the Poles. This was to turn the Polish lower classes into a modern nation and put a stop to the successes of [[Germanization]] and [[Russification]], pursued by the occupiers of [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth|partitioned Poland]].<ref name="Janowski">{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ieF7NYaEqQYC&lpg=PA166&ots=LCYj19A4qz&dq=%22organic%20work%22%20Herbert%20Spencer&pg=PA166#v=onepage&q=%22the%20idea%20of%20organic%20work%22%20Herbert%20Spencer&f=false | title=The Rise of Positivism | publisher=Central European University Press | work=Polish Liberal Thought Before 1918 | year=2004 | accessdate=September 7, 2012 | author=Maciej Janowski | page=166 | isbn=9639241180}}</ref>
==History== Increasing oppression at Russian hands after failed national uprisings (the [[November Uprising]] of 1830-1831 and the [[January Uprising]] of 1863-1864) finally convinced Polish leaders that the insurrection was premature at best and perhaps fundamentally misguided and counterproductive.<ref name="Cieplak">{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QOc3RKTiNBEC&lpg=PA88&ots=dDmzZLcwEp&dq=%22organic%20work%22%20Herbert%20Spencer&pg=PA88#v=onepage&q=%22organic%20work%22%20%22after%20Herbert%20Spencer%22&f=false | title=The Znak group in Poland | publisher=Ardent Media | work=Poland Since 1956: Readings and Essays on Polish Government and Politics | year=1972 | accessdate=September 7, 2012 | author=Tadeusz N. Cieplak | pages=88}}</ref> During the decades that followed, Poles largely forsook the goal of immediate independence and turned instead to fortifying the nation through the subtler means of education, economic development, and modernization. This approach took the name Organic Work for its philosophy of strengthening Polish society at the grass roots, influenced by [[positivism in Poland|positivism]]. For some, the adoption of Organic Work meant permanent resignation to foreign rule, but many advocates recommended it as a strategy to combat repression while awaiting an eventual opportunity to achieve self-government.
==Methods== Neither as colorful as the Polish rebellions, nor as loftily enshrined in [[national memory]], the quotidian methods of organic work proved well suited to the political conditions of the later nineteenth century. The international balance of forces did not favour the recovery of Polish statehood at that time given that both Russia and Germany appeared bent on the eventual eradication of Polish national identity. The [[German Empire]], established in 1871 as an expanded version of the [[Prussia]]n state, aimed at the assimilation of its eastern provinces inhabited by Poles. At the same time, St. Petersburg attempted to [[Russification|russify]] the former [[Congress Poland|Congress Kingdom]], joining Berlin in levying restrictions against use of the Polish language and cultural expression. Poles under Russian and German rule also endured official campaigns against the [[Roman Catholic]] Church: the Cultural Struggle ([[Kulturkampf]]) of Chancellor [[Otto von Bismarck]] to bring the Roman Catholic Church under state control and the Russian campaign to replace Catholicism by extending [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodoxy]] throughout the empire.
==Toleration== The Polish subjects under Austrian jurisdiction (after 1867 the [[Habsburg]] Empire was commonly known as [[Austria-Hungary]]) confronted a generally more lenient regime. Poles suffered no religious persecution in predominantly Catholic [[Austria]], and Vienna counted on the Polish nobility as allies in the complex political calculus of its multinational realm. In return for loyalty, Austrian Poland, or [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]], received considerable administrative and cultural autonomy. Galicia gained a reputation as an oasis of toleration amidst the oppression of German and Russian Poland. The Galician provincial [[Sejm]] acted as a semiautonomous parliamentary body, and Poles represented the region in the empire government in Vienna. In the late 1800s, the universities of [[Krakow]] and [[Lwów]] became the centers of Polish intellectual activity, and Kraków became the center of Polish art and thought. Even after the restoration of independence, many residents of southern Poland retained a touch of nostalgia for the days of the Habsburg Empire.

{{Infobox Website | name = OttoBib.com | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | url = http://www.ottobib.com/ | commercial = | type = [[metasearch]] | language = | registration = no | owner = jonathanotto.com | author = Jonathan Otto | launch date = January 2006 | current status = operational | revenue = }} '''OttoBib.com''' is a website with a free tool to generate an alphabetized [[bibliography]] of books from a list of [[International Standard Book Number]]s (ISBN) with output in [[MLA Style Manual|MLA]], [[APA style|APA]], [[The Chicago Manual of Style|Chicago]]/[[Turabian]], [[BibTeX]] and Wikipedia {{tl|cite book}} format.{{cite web |url=http://www.lifehacker.com/software/back-to-school/back-to-school-automate-your-citations-with-ottobib-204479.php |title=Back to School: Automate your citations with Ottobib |publisher=[[Lifehacker.com]] |date=October 2, 2006 |author=Boswell, Wendy}} Each query also generates a "temporary" [[permalink]] (self-destructs in about one month) which can be used to recall the bibliography without reentering the ISBN data. The site is a [[metasearch engine]], integrating data from several sources, including the U.S. [[Library of Congress]] API, the [[Amazon.com]] database of books, and [[ISBNdb.com]]. OttoBib accepts ISBNs with either 10 or 13 digits. == Background == OttoBib.com was started as a hobby project in 2006 by Jonathan Otto, a then 4th year undergraduate at the [[University of Wisconsin–La Crosse]], USA.[http://www.neobinaries.com/apps/Category/Search%20Engines/OttoBib.aspx Web 2.0 Application Listings] -- About the company It was originally called "That's Crazy Hot!" but the name was quickly changed to OttoBib because the original title was "not suitable for the academic environment and consequently won't take off."{{cite web | url = http://jonathanotto.com/2006/1/13/21/55/Thats-Crazy-Hot | title = That's Crazy Hot! | date = January 13, 2006 | author = Jonathan Otto | work = OttoBib Blog | accessdate = 2007-02-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061101041332/http://jonathanotto.com/2006/1/13/21/55/Thats-Crazy-Hot |archivedate = 2006-11-01}} The original inspiration for the site came from [[Seth Godin]]'s January 3, 2006 blog post on "Stuck Systems", where he wrote:
A quick online search didn't turn up what seemed obvious to me: a free service that would allow a writer to type in all the ISBNs used in creating a paper and then generate two things: # a bibliography based on looking up the data online and # a web page that would allow the reader/teacher to see the books, their covers... etc.[http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2006/01/stuck_systems.html Stuck systems] January 3, 2006 post on [[Seth Godin]]'s Blog
== Functionality == OttoBib.com performs the two basic functions outlined. Marcus P. Zillman, an Internet information retrieval consultant and speaker said "this website is the start of a new paradigm of citing sources."[http://zillman.blogspot.com/2006/12/ottobib-free-auto-bibliography.html Internet Happenings, Events and Sources] December 11, 2006 post by Marcus P. Zillman, accessed December 24, 2006 [[Jason Clarke (writer)|Jason Clarke]], a writer and web developer, said OttoBib is a "tool that solves a simple problem in a simple manner."[http://www.downloadsquad.com/2006/09/20/ottobib-automatic-bibliographies-for-back-to-schoolers/ Downloadsquad review] posted Sep 20, 2006 by [[Jason Clarke (writer)|Jason Clarke]] == Developments == In January 2007, OttoBib introduced a [[Representational State Transfer|REST]] interface to allow a citation to be generated from a URL that contains the ISBN. For example, {{ISBN|0-19-511797-2}} can be used in the URL: http://ottobib.com/isbn/0195117972/apa to display [[James T. Patterson (historian)|Patterson, J.]], (1997). ''[[Oxford History of the United States|Grand Expectations]]''. Oxford Oxfordshire: Oxford University Press. In February 2007, OttoBib introduced the ability to request citations in [[BibTeX]] and Wikipedia {{tl|cite book}} formats. == See also == * [[Citation creator]] * [[Bibliographic database]] * [[Delicious Library]] * [[ISBNdb.com]] * [[Reference management software]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *{{official website|http://www.ottobib.com/}} [[Category:Reference management software]] [[Category:Bibliography]] [[Category:Book websites]] [[Category:Free-content websites]] [[Category:Library 2.0]]

'''[[Commercial law]]''' – body of [[law]] that governs [[business]] and [[commerce|commercial]] transactions. It is often considered to be a branch of [[Civil law (common law)|civil law]] and deals with issues of both [[private law]] and [[public law]]. It is also called '''business law'''.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== What ''type'' of thing is commercial law? ==
Commercial law can be described as all of the following:
* Branch of [[law]] – law is a [[system]] of rules and guidelines which are enforced through [[social]] [[institution]]s to govern behavior, wherever possible.<ref>Robertson, ''Crimes against humanity'', 90; see "[[analytical jurisprudence]]" for extensive debate on what law is; in ''[[The Concept of Law]]'' Hart argued law is a "system of rules" (Campbell, ''The Contribution of Legal Studies'', 184); Austin said law was "the command of a sovereign, backed by the threat of a sanction" (Bix, [http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/austin-john/#3 John Austin]); Dworkin describes law as an "interpretive concept" to achieve [[justice]] (Dworkin, ''[[Law's Empire]]'', 410); and Raz argues law is an "authority" to mediate people's interests (Raz, ''The Authority of Law'', 3–36).</ref>
<ref>MR PAUL MNAGAWA</ref>

{{other uses|Privilege (disambiguation)}} {{one source|date=June 2009}} A '''privilege''' is a certain entitlement to [[immunity from prosecution|immunity]] granted by the state or another authority to a restricted group, either by birth or on a conditional basis. Land-titles and taxi medallions are pronounced examples of transferable privilege. These can be revoked in certain circumstances. In modern democratic states, a ''privilege'' is conditional and granted only after birth. By contrast, a ''[[right]]'' is an inherent, irrevocable entitlement held by all citizens or all human beings from the moment of birth. Various examples of old [[common law]] privilege still exist, to title deeds, for example.<ref>Suzanna McNichol, ''The Law of Privilege'' (1st ed., 1992)</ref> Etymologically, a privilege (''privilegium'') means a "private law", or rule relating to a specific individual or institution.
Note that the principles of conduct that members of the legal profession observe in their practice are called Legal ethics. <ref>https://www.britannica.com/topic/legal-ethics</ref>
[[Boniface]]'s [[Fulda monastery|abbey of Fulda]], to cite an early and prominent example, was granted ''[[privilege (canon law)|privilegium]]'', setting the abbot in direct contact with the pope, bypassing the jurisdiction of the local bishop.
One of the objectives of the [[French Revolution]] was the abolition of privilege. This meant the removal of separate laws for different [[social class]]es ([[nobility]], [[clergy]], and ordinary people), instead subjecting everyone to the same common law. Privileges were abolished by the [[National Constituent Assembly (France)|National Constituent Assembly]] on August 4, 1789.
==Protection from subpoena== One common legal privilege in the United States and Commonwealth countries is protection from the requirement to testify or provide documents in certain situations (see [[privilege (evidence)]]). This is granted to people based on a professional or personal relationship (such as being the lawyer, doctor, or spouse of the accused) and not based on circumstances of birth.

{{essay-like|date=June 2009}} '''Psychological theories of magic''' treat magic as a personal phenomenon intended to meet individual needs, as opposed to a social phenomenon serving a collective purpose.
==Theories== ===Psychosis===
Among the earliest psychological theories is the psychosis theory, advanced by [[Sigmund Freud]].<ref>Freud, S. Totem and taboo: Resemblances between the psychic lives of savages and neurotics. London: Routledge Kegan Paul (1960). (Original work published 1913).</ref> According to this theory, “primitive man” is not a rational being, and in fact [[magical thinking]] bears a strong resemblance to neuroses. However, this conclusion has come into question, as more recent psychological theory acknowledges that psychological testing does not cross cultures with complete accuracy.<ref>Gleitman, H., Reisberg, D., & Gross, J. Psychology, 7th edition. New York, NY: W. W. Norton & Co (2007). </ref>
===Bad science=== In contrast, the “bad science” model claims that primitive man is rational, and magical beliefs come into existence as he tries to explain puzzling phenomena without enough information. According to this theory, the magician is an early form of scientist who merely lacks adequate data. In [[Edward Burnett Tylor]]’s version of this theory, the magician’s folly is in mistaking an ideal connection for a real one; the magician believes that thematically-linked items can influence one another by virtue of their similarity.<ref>Evans-Pritchard, E.E. Theories of Primitive Religion. Oxford: Oxford University Press (1977), p.p. 26-27.</ref> For example, the [[Azande]] rub crocodile teeth on banana plants to make them fruitful (because crocodile teeth grow continuously). The property of [[fertility]] can spread from a symbol of fertility (the crocodile tooth) to the intended target (the banana tree). Michael F. Brown observes that many Aguaruna taboos can be understood as preventing undesired connections.
===Symbolic action=== The symbolic action theory understands magic as a course of action taken when there exists an emotional (psychological) need for action, but no practical option exists. In [[R.R. Marett]]’s example, it is a magical action when a man, betrayed by his mistress, gathers photographs of her and burns them.<ref>R.R. Marett. The Threshold of Religion, 2nd edition. (1914). Summary courtesy of Evans-Pritchard, Theories of Primitive Religion, p.p. 33-34.</ref> This interpretation presents a modern analog of the [[voodoo doll]]. As Marett describes, if the emotional situation proves common enough, the response becomes a socially-codified norm which outsiders understand as magic and which Marett labels “developed magic”. Claude Lévi-Strauss<ref>Lévi-Strauss, Claude. ''The Effectiveness of Symbols.''</ref> and Ariel Glucklich<ref>Glucklich, Ariel. ''The End of Magic.'' New York: Oxford University Press (1997).</ref> expand upon symbolic theory, positing that magic can serve as a form of psychotherapy or [[New Age]] science, accomplishing real results by what amounts to the [[placebo effect]]. The effects of such magic would be made real through its effect on the individual person as demonstrated in their life and actions.
===Anxiety relief=== According to theories of anxiety relief and control, people turn to magical beliefs when there exists a sense of uncertainty and potential danger and little to do about it. Magic is used to restore a sense of control. In support of this theory, research indicates that superstitious behavior is invoked more often in high stress situations, especially by people with a greater desire for control.<ref>Keinan, Giora. ''The effects of stress and desire for control on superstitious behavior.'' Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin Vol. 28, No. 1. Society for Personality and Social Psychology, Inc. (2002).</ref> It is proposed that one reason (but not necessarily the only reason) for the persistence of magic rituals is that the ritual activates vigilance-precaution systems – that is to say, that the rituals prompt their own use by creating a feeling of insecurity and then proposing themselves as precautions.<ref>Boyer, Pascal and Pierre Liénard. ''Ritual behavior in obsessive and normal individuals.'' Association for Psychological Science (2008).</ref> [[Pascal Boyer]] and Pierre Liénard propose that the shape rituals take results from goal demotion and attentional focus on lower level representation.<ref>Boyer, Pascal and Pierre Liénard. ''Ritual behavior in obsessive and normal individuals.'' Association for Psychological Science (2008).</ref> Levels of representation were previously described by J.M. Zacks and [[Barbara Tversky]].<ref>Zacks, J.M. and B. Tversky. ''Event structure in perception and conception.'' Psychological Bulletin, 127, 3-21. (2001).</ref> At the lowest level are simple gestures (such as putting the left foot in a shoe). At the mid-level are behavioral episodes (such as putting one’s shoes on). At the highest level are scripts (such as getting dressed to go out). Ordinarily, people describe and recall behavior in terms of the middle level of behavioral episodes{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}. In studies of [[obsessive-compulsive]] rituals, focus shifts to the lower level of gestures, resulting in goal demotion. For example, an obsessive-compulsive cleaning ritual may overemphasize the order, direction, and number of wipes used to clean the surface. The goal becomes less important than the actions used to achieve the goal, with the implication that magic rituals can persist without efficacy because the intent is lost within the act. Debate remains as to whether studies of obsessive-compulsive rituals can be extended to describe other kinds of rituals.
